notesStmt.note: Title from colophon, which reads: Here endeth the discripcion of Britayne the, whiche conteyneth englond wales and scotland .. which I haue taken oute of Policronicon, and bicause it is necessarie to alle englisshmen to knowe the propretees co[m]moditees [and] meruailles of them, therfore I haue sette them in enprinte according to the translacion of Treuisa, whiche atte request of the lord Barkeley translated the book of Policronicon in to englissh, fynysshed by me william Ca[and]ton the xviij. day of August the yere of our lord god M.CCCC.lxxx. and the xx. yere of the regne of kyng Edward the fourthe.

Text, [A]1v, begins "Hit is so that in many and diuerse places the comyn cronicles of englond ben had ..". Text proper begins on [A]2r: "The names of this iland. Capitulo j. fIrst as Galfride saith this lande was named Albion ..".
The "x" in "Caxton" in the colophon is misprinted as a Tironian "et".
Sometimes bound with an edition of "Chronicles of England" (STC 9991 et seq.).
Identified as STC 13440+ on UMI microfilm reel 519.
Reproductions of the originals in the British Library and the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
Appears at reel 13 (British Library copy) and at reel 519 (Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery copy).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ¬∂ The names of this Iland Capitulo. j.
div.p: FIr≈øt as Galfride ≈øaith this lande was named Albion after the name of Albyne the olde≈øt doughter of Diocle≈ølan / and had xxxij. ≈øu≈øtres / And they were fir≈øt that enhabited this lande / And becau≈øe ≈øhe was the olde≈øt ≈øu≈øter ≈øhe named this lond Albion after her owne name as the cronicle reher≈øeth / Othir ≈øaye that this lond was named Albion as it where the white londe of white rockes aboute the clines of the ≈øee that were ≈øeyne fro ferre ¬∂ Afterward Brute conquered this lond and callid it Brytayn after his owne name Thenne Saxons or engli≈ø≈øhmen conquered this lond and callid it Anglia that is Englond / Or it is callid Anglia of a quene that owed this lande that was named Angela and was a noble dukes doughter of the Saxons / Or as y≈øid ≈øeyth ethi. xv. Anglia hath that name as it were an angle and a corner of the world Ozels as Beda ≈øaith li. j. Seynt Grectorie ≈øawe engli≈ø≈øh children to ≈øelle at Rome and he accorded to the name of the londe / and ≈øayde they ber, ≈øothly anglis / for ther face ≈øhyned as angels / for the noblede of the londe ≈øhone in the children faces / Alfre. The britty≈ø≈øh anglia is cleped the othir world / and for grete plente of all good the grete Charles called it his owne chambre / SolinÍù∞. The edge of the freni≈øh clif ≈øhold be the ende of the world / yf the ylonde of britayn ne were not / whiche is worthy to haue the name of an othir world / Alfre. This Ilonde is callid in≈øula for it is in ≈øalo / that is the ≈øee / and is beten of with diuer≈øe cours of waters with ≈øtremez and with wawes of the ≈øce

div.head: ¬∂ Of the ≈øettyng boundyng lengthe & brede of this londe Ca. ij
div.p:
THis britayn is acounted a noble londe bothe in our ≈øtories and al≈øo in the ≈øtories of grekes / and is ≈øette ayen≈øte Germania. Gallia. Fraunce & ≈øpayne bitwene the north and the we≈øt and the ≈øee bitwene / This londe is fyfty myle from the clyf of the men that he called morini ge≈ø≈øorico / Beda li. j. And for this Ilonde lyeth vnder the north hede of the worlde / hit hath lyght and bright nyghtes in the ≈øomer tyme / So that oft tyme at mydnyght men haue que≈øtions and doubte wethir it be euen tyde or dawyng / that is for the tyme of the yere that the ≈øonne goth not fer vnder the erthe by nyght / but pa≈ø≈øeth by the north ≈øyde and cometh ≈øone in to the e≈øte agayn / And therfore in the ≈øomer ben ther dayes ful longe of xviij. houres / And the nyghtes of vj. houres And after in the wynter ben longe nyghtes of xviij. houres / and
≈øhort dayes of vj. houres Al≈øo in armenia macedonia Italia and in othir londes of the ≈øame lyne the lenge≈øt day and lenge≈øt nyght al≈øo is of xv. houres / and the ≈øhorte≈øt day or nyght is of ix. houres PliÍù∞ in meroe / that Ilonde is chief of black meÃÑ / ther is the lenge≈øt day xij. houres / In alexandria in egipt of xiij. houres / In Italia of xv. houres / In Britayne of xviij. houres / In the Ilonde named Tylem alle the vj. ≈øomer monethes is day / and alle the ≈øixe wynter monthes is nyght / Y≈øido. li. xiiij. Britayne is ≈øette within Ocean as it were withoute the world / and is ≈øette ayen≈øt fraunce and ≈øpayne / Giraldus Britayne is endlong and larger in the myddel than in thendes / OroÍù∞ / Britayne ≈øtretcheth in lengthe out of the ≈øouth in to the north / and in the ≈øouthe≈øt ≈øide / hit hath frauÃÑce in the ≈øouth ≈øpayne / In the north norwey / and in the we≈øt hibernia that is Irlonde / whan ≈øhipmen pa≈ø≈øen the next clyf of that londe they ≈øee a cite that heet rutpi mouth / Beda li. j. That cite is now called ≈øhortly of engli≈ø≈øhmen Reptace≈øtre / Solinus / Britayne is viij. C. myle of lengthe / and it be moten from the clyf of Totene≈ø≈øe to the angle of Calidon / Alfre. That is from pen with≈øtrete xv. myle beyonde michels ≈øtowe in cornewaille / vnto Catene≈ø≈øe that is be yonde ≈øcotland / and Britayne is more than ij. C. myle brode froÃÑ meuenia that is the vtteme≈øt place in wales vnto yarmouth in norffolke / Beda Only outake the lenge≈øt out ≈øheting of diuer≈øe forlondes with the which Britayne is all aboute xlviij. ≈øithe lxx thou≈øand paas

div.head: ¬∂ Of the worthynes and prerogatiues Ca. iij
div.p:
IS fraunce pa≈ø≈øeth Britayne ≈øo Britayne pa≈ø≈øeth Irlond in feyr weder and noblete / but not in helthe / Beda li. j ‚Ä¢ For this Ilonde is be≈øte to bringe forth trees and fruyt / Ruthern and bee≈øtis / And wyn groweth therin in ≈øomme place The londe hath plente of fowles and of bee≈øtis of diuerce maner kynde / The londe is plenteuous & the ≈øee al≈øo / The londe is noble copious and riche of noble welles and ryuers wyth plente of fi≈ø≈øhe / Ther is grete plente of ≈ømall fi≈ø≈øhe of ≈øamon and of celes / Wilhel. de ponÃÑ. li. iij. So that the peple in ≈øomme place fedeth their ≈øwyne with fy≈ø≈øhe / Beda libro primo / There ben oftymes taken Dolphyns / S√©e calues / and balaynes grete fy≈ø≈øhes as whales kynde / and diuer≈øe maner ≈øhelfy≈ø≈øhe / amonge whiche ≈øhelfy≈ø≈øhe ben mu≈økles that within hem haue Margeri peerles of all maner
of colour and hewe of rody and rede purpure and of blewe / and ≈øpecially and mo≈øt of whyte There is al≈øo plente of ≈øhellefy≈ø≈øhe that men dyen ther with fyn reed / the redenes ther of is wonder fayre and ≈øtable / and ≈øteyneth neuer with colde ne with hete with weet ne with drye / But euer the older the colour is the fayrer / Ther ben al≈øo ≈øaltwelles and hote welles / ther of rennen ≈øtremes of hote bathes departed in to diuer≈øe places accordyng / for man and woman of all maner age olde or yonge / Ba≈øilius ≈øeith that the water that renneth and pa≈ø≈øeth by wynes of certayn me talle taketh in his cours grete hete / This Ilond is plenteuous of wynes of metuls / bras of yren / of lede / of tyn / and of ≈øiluer al≈øo. PliÍù∞ libro vj. ca. vj. In this Ilonde vnder the turf of the londe is good marle founden / the thryfte of the fatnes dryeth hym ≈øelfe therin / So that euer the thikker the felde is marled / the better coin it wole bere / There is al≈øo anothir maner whyte marle / that the londe is better foure ≈øcore yere that ther with is marled

Solinus In this Ilonde groweth a ≈øtone that is callid gagates yf ye wyll knowe his fayrne≈ø≈øe / it is black as gemmes ben / Yf ye wyll knowe his kynde / hit brenneth in water and quenchith in oyle and as to his myght / yf the ≈øtone be froted and chauffed hit holdelth what hym neygheth as ≈øuccuns a ≈øtone that is ≈øo named / Y≈øidorus libro decimoquinto. Ther ben ≈øheep that berin good wulle / There ben many hertes and wylde be≈øtes and fewe wolues / therfore ≈øheep ben the ≈øurer withoute kepyng lefte in the felde R / In this Ilonde al≈øo ben many atees and townes faire and noble and riche / many grete riuers and ≈øtremes with grete plente of fy≈ø≈øhe / many fayre woodes and grete / with right many be≈øtes tame and wilde / The erthe of that londe is copyous of metall oor / and of ≈øaltwelles / of quareyes of marble of dmer≈øe maner ≈øtones / of reed of whyte of ≈øofte and of „Äà‚óä„Äâ / of chalke and of whyte lyme / Ther is al≈øo whyte clay and reed for to make pottes / crokkes / ≈øtenes / and othir ve≈ø≈øell and brente tyle to couere with hou≈øes and chirches / as it were in the othir ≈øamia / that is named ≈øamos al≈øo / Flaundres loueth well the wulle of this londe And holand the ≈økynnes and felles of alle maner of be≈øtes / Guyan the yron and the leed / Irlonde the oor and the ≈øalt / Alle Europa loueth and de≈øireth the whyte metall of this londe / Alfredus / Britayne hath ynow of mater that ther nedeth to bye and ≈øelle / or is nedefull to mannes v≈øe / ther lacketh nethir ≈øalt ne yron / Therfore a ver≈øifiour in his metre prey≈øeth this londe in
this maner / Englond is a good londe fruytfull of wolle / but it is a corner / Englond is full of pleye / fre men / well worthy to pleye / fre men / fre tonges / fre hertes / and fre ben all their thinges / theyr honde is more fre and better than their tonge / Al≈øo englond is beauteuous of londe / flour of londes all aboute that londe is ful paid with fruyt & good of his owne / that londe releueth ≈øtraunge men that hath nede therto And whan honger greueth othir londes that londe fedeth hem / That londe berith fruyt & corne good ynouh That londe is well at ce≈øe / as longe as men lyue in pees / E≈øt & we≈øt in eche lond / ben knowen well the hauenes of englond / her ≈øhippes foundes & ofte helpeth many londes / their mete & money / men haue ther more comyn alway / And for to lerne men gladly yeue yeftes In londe & ≈øtronde / wyde ≈øpeke men of englond / londe hony mylke che≈øe this Ilonde therof ≈øhall bere the pri≈øe / This Ilonde hath no nede to othir londes / alle londes mu≈øte ≈øeche helpe at this allone / Of the lykyng of their woun / myght wonder kyng ≈øalomon / the ryche≈ø≈øe that ther is an / wolde de≈øire Octauian

div.head: ¬∂ Of the meruailles & wondres Ca. iiij.
div.p:
IN Britayne ben hoot welles / well arayed & a dre≈ø≈øyd to the v≈øe of maÃÑkynde / mai≈øtre≈ø≈øe of thilke welles is the grete ≈øpirite of minerua / In her hous the fyre endureth alway that neuer chaungeth in to a≈ø≈øhes / but there the fyre ≈ølaketh / hit chaungeth in to ≈øtone clottes / Alfre. In Britayne ben many wondres nethebes foure ben mo≈øt wonderfull / The fir≈øt is at pectoÃÑ ther bloweth ≈øo ≈øtronge wynde out of the chynes of the erthe / that it ca≈øteth vp agayne clothes that men ca≈øte in The ≈øeconde is at ≈øton henge be≈øides ≈øaleofbury / ther ben grete ≈øtones & wonder huge & ben rered an heygh as it were yates / ≈øo that ther famen yates ≈øette vpon othir yates / Netheles it is not knowen clerly ne aperceyued how & wherfor they hen ≈øo arered and ≈øo wonderfully honged The thirde is atte cherdhoke / there is a grete holownes vnder erthe / ofte many men haue walked therin & haue ≈øeen riuers & ≈øtremes / but nowher can they fynde none ende / The fourthe is that rayne is ≈øeen rey≈øed vpon hilles & anone y≈øpronge aboute in the feldes / Al≈øo ther is a grete ponde that conteyneth lx. Ilondes couenable for men to duelle in / that ponde is biclipped aboute with vj. ≈øcore roches / and vpon euery roche an egles ne≈øt / And lx. Ryuers rennen in to that ponde / & none of hem all renne in to the ≈øee but one / Ther is a
ponde clo≈øed aboute with a wal of tyle and of ≈øtone / In that ponde men wa≈ø≈øh and bathe well ofte / And euery man fel ‚Ä¢ th the water hoot or colde right as he wyll hym ≈øelfe / Ther ben ≈øalt welles fer from the ≈øee and ben ≈øalt al the weke longe vnto ≈øaterday none and fre≈ø≈øh fro ≈øaterday none vnto monday / The water of the≈øe welles whan it is ≈øoden torneth in to ≈ømall ≈øalt fayre and whyte Al≈øo ther is a ponde / the water therof hath wonder wirchyng / for though all an hoo≈øt ≈øtode by the ponde and torned their face thidderward the water wold drawe hym violently toward the ponde and wete all their clothes / ≈øo ≈øhold hor≈øe be drawen in the ≈øame wy≈øe / And yf the face be torned away fro the water / the water noyeth not / There is a welle that no ≈øtreme renneth fro / nethir therto / and yet foure maner fi≈ø≈øhes be taken therin / that welle is but xx. foote longe and xx. fote brode / and not depe but to the kne / and clo≈øeth with hygh bankes on euery ≈øide / In the contrey aboute wynche≈øtre is a denne or a caue / oute of that caue bloweth alway a ≈øtronge wynde / ≈øo that noman may endure to ≈øtonde to fore that deÃÑne or caue Therre is al≈øo a pond that torneth tree in to yron yf it be ther in a yere / And ≈øo trees ben ≈øhapen in to whe≈øtones / Al≈øo ther is in the toppe of an hylle a buriels euery man that cometh and meteth that buryel / he ≈øhall fynde it euen of his owne bengthe and me≈øure And yf a pilgrym knele therto / anone he ≈øhall be alle fre≈ø≈øh and fele no grief of werynes / Gir. in top. Fa≈øt by the myn≈øter of wyn burney that is not fer fro bathe / is a wode that bereth moche fruyt yf the trees of that wode falle in to water or grounde that is neyh aud lye there all a yere / the tre ‚Ä¢ tornen in to ≈øtones / Gir. in itinere vuder the cite of che≈øtr „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ enneth that riuer dee / that now departeth Englond and wale „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
chaunged euery moneth his fordes as men of the contrey ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ llen / and leueth ofte the chanel / but whether the water drawe more toward Englond or toward wales to what ≈øide that it be / that yere men of that ≈øide haue the wer≈øe ende and be ouer≈øette / And men of that othir ≈øide ≈øhall haue better ende and ben at their aboue / whan the water ≈øo chaungith his cours hit bodeth ≈øuch happes / This riuer dee renneth and cometh oute of a lake that hete pymblemere / In this riuer is grete plente of ≈øamon / netheles in the lake is neur ≈øamon founden / Wilhel. de re. li. ij Take hede how grete light & brightnes of goddes myldenes hath be ≈øhewd vpon Engli≈ø≈øhmen / ≈øith they torned fir≈øt to right beleue / So that of no men in one prouynce ben founden ≈øo many hole bodies of men after her deth in lyknes of euerla≈øtyngnes that ≈øhall
be after the day of dome / as it well ≈øemeth in the≈øe holyi≈øeintes / Edeldrede Edmonde / the kyng Elphege / Edgar Cutberd & ≈øeint Edward & many othir / I trowe that it be do by ≈øpeciall grace of god Almyghty for the nacion that is ≈øette as it were without the world ≈øhold take hede to buryng of bodyes withoute corrupcion and roting / and ben the more bolde and ≈øtedfa≈øt for to tru≈øte on the fynall ary≈øing of dede bodyes for to la≈øte euermore after the day of dome

div.head: ¬∂ Of the chief parties of the londe Ca. v
div.p:
AFter the fir≈øt Brutes tyme the Ilonde of Britayne begaÃÑ for to haue the principall parties that ben loegria cambria that is wales / And Albania that is now ≈øcotlond
‚Ä¢ oegria had that name of locrinus that was Brutes olde≈øt ≈øone / and heet loegria as it were locrinus londe / bnt now loegria is called englonde / The boundes & merkes were therof ≈øomtyme the fren≈ø≈øh ≈øee bothe by ee≈øt & by ≈øonth / Beda li. j. ca. ij. And by north two armes of the ≈øee that breketh fer in to the londe eyther ayen≈øt othir / But they reche not to gydres / the ee≈øt arme of thylke tweyne beginneth aboute a two li ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll myle fro the myn≈øtre of Ebburcuring In the we≈øt ≈øide of penulton in that arme is a toune that is called Guydy / The we≈øt arme of thilke tweyne hath in the right ≈øide a ≈øtrong cite that heet Alcliud which in her langage is called Clirt≈øtone and ≈øtandeth vpon a riuer that is called Clynt al≈øo / R / Somme men wold mene that loegria endeth at humbre / and ≈øtretcheth no ferther northward / The ≈øeconde partie of Britayne is called Albania that is ≈øcotland and hath that name of Albanactus brutes ≈øone and ≈øtretcheth fro the for≈øaid two armes of the ≈øee north ward vnto the ≈øee of Norwaye / Netheles the ≈øouth parties of Albania where as pictes duelled ≈øomtyme / lieth from the water of twede vnto the ≈øcotti≈ø≈øh ≈øee / All that longed ≈øomtyme to the kyngdome of Northumberland brenicorn the north≈øide of Northumberlond fro the fir≈øt tyme of engli≈ø≈øh kynges / to that tyme whan kynadius kyng of ≈øcotland that was Alpinus ≈øone dyde away the pictes / and ≈øo Ioyned that contrey to the kyngdome of ≈øcotland The thirde partie of britayne is wales wallia that heet Cambria al≈øo / and had that name Cambria of Camber Brutes ≈øone / for he was prince of wales / In the ce≈øt ≈øide Seuarn departed ≈øomtyme bitwene englond and wales / Bnt now in the north≈øide the riuer
dee at Che≈øtre / and in the ≈øouth the riuer that is named vaga at the Ca≈øtell of ≈øtrigelin departeth englond & wales / Al≈øo kynge Offa for to haue a di≈øtinction for euermore bitwene the kynges of englond and of wales made a longe dyche that ≈øtretcheth forth oute of the ≈øouth≈øide by Bri≈øtow vnder the hilles of wales northward and pa≈ø≈øeth the riuers Seuarn and dee almo≈øt to the heedes & vnto the mouth of the riuer dee beyonde Che≈øtre fa≈øt by the ca≈øtell it renneth bitwene colehill and the myn≈øtre of ba≈øingwerk in to the ≈øee / This dyche is yet in many places ≈øeen / In ≈øeint Edwardes tyme wal≈ø≈øhmen ≈øhold not pa≈ø≈øe that dyche with wepen vpon a grete payne / And that was at erle haroldes procuring as it ≈øhall be ≈øaid here after / But now in eyther ≈øides bothe ayondhalf and a this half the dyche and ≈øpecially in the ≈øhyres of Ch≈øtre of Srow≈øbury and of herford in many places ben Engli≈ø≈øhmen and wal≈ø≈øhmen medlyd to gydres

div.head: ¬∂ Of the Ilondes therto adiacent Capitulo ≈øexte.
div.p:
BRytayne hath thre Ilondes that ben nygh and longen therto all without the Ilondes orcades / as it were an≈øuering to the thre chief parties of britayne / For the Ile of wyght longeth and lieth to loegria that is englond / The Ilonde Mon that is called Ange≈øeya al≈øo longeth to wales / & the Ilonde Eubonia that hath two othir names & is called Menaiua & maÃÑ al ≈øo / whiche longeth to ≈øcotlonde / And all the≈øe thre Ilondes wyght Mon and Man ben almo≈øt yliche moche / and of the like quantite of the which thre all arewe now folo weth oure ≈øpeche / Beda li. j. ca. iij. Claudius ≈øence va≈øpa≈øianÍù∞ and va≈øpa≈øianus wan wyght and wyght ≈øtretcheth oute of the ee≈øt in to the we≈øt xxx. myle longe / And oute of the ≈øouth in to the north xij. myle / and is in the ee≈øt ≈øide ≈øix myle fro the ≈øouth clyf of Britayne / and thre myle in the we≈øt ≈øide / Beda li. iiij. ca. v. The me≈øure of this Ilonde as Engli≈ø≈øhmen ge≈ø≈øe is a M. hou≈øholdes and two hondred / Gir. in itinere. Mon that is called Angle≈øeya al≈øo is departed from north wales by a ≈øhort arme of the ≈øee as it were ij. myle brode In mon ben iij. C. tounes lxiij. & ben acoÃÑpded for caÃÑdredes yt ben iij. hondredes the Ilonde is as it were xxx. myle longe & xij. myle brode / Candredus is ≈øo moch londe as coÃÑteyneth an C. tounes / y‚Ä¢ name candredÍù∞ is made out of two langages of britti≈ø≈øh & of Iri≈ø≈øh in pray≈øing
of this Ilonde wal≈ø≈øhinen be wonde to ≈øaye a prouerbe and an olde ≈øawe / mon mam kembry / that is to ≈øaye in engli≈ø≈øh / that londe is ≈øo good that it ≈øemeth that it wolde fynde corn ynow for all the men of wales Therfor virgyls u≈øes may be acordyng therto / as moch as gua wes / be≈øtes longe Inneth dawes / So moche efte / bryngeth cold dewe in a nyght / In that arme of the ≈øee that departeth this londe and north wales / is a ≈øwolow that draweth ≈øhippes to it that ≈øaylleth by and ≈øwoloweth hem in / right as doth Cilla and Caribdis that ben two perilous places in the ≈øee of myddell erthe / Therfore men may not ≈øaille by this ≈øwalow / but ≈ølyly atte full ≈øee / R Of the meruaylles and woundres of the Ilond Mon thou ≈øhalt fynde to fore in the chapitre of wales / Gir. in itinere / The third IloÃÑ de that is called bothe Eubonia and Menauia that is man ≈øton / deth in the myddell bitwene the Iri≈ø≈øh vl≈øter and the ≈øcotty≈ø≈øh galle waye / as it were in the nauel of the ≈øee / Beda li. ij. ca. ix. This Ilonde man conteyneth as it were two Ilondes / The fir≈øt is ≈øouthward the more contrey and the better corn londe / and condeyneth ix. c. and lx. hou≈øholdes. The ≈øcconde condeyneth the ≈øpace of CCC. and moo as engli≈ø≈øhmen ge≈ø≈øe / Gir. in top. Somtyme was ≈øtryfe wether this Ilonde Man ≈øholde longe to Brytayne or to Irlonde And for as moche as venemous woemes that were brought the der lyued there / It was Iugged that the Ilonde Man ≈øholde longe to Briteyne / R / In that Ilonde is ≈øortilege and wicchecraft v≈øed For women there ≈øelle to ≈øhippmen wynde as it were clo≈øed vnder thre knottes of threde / ≈øo that the more wynde he wole haue / the mo knottes he mu≈øte vndo / Ther ofte by day tyme men of that londe ≈øeen men that ben deed to fore hond beheded or hoole and what deth they deyde Aliens ≈øette their feet vpon feet of the men of that londe for to ≈øee ≈øuche ≈øightes as the men of that lond doon / Beda li. ij. Scottes duelled fir≈øt in this Ilond / Thanatos that is Tenet and is an Ilonde be≈øides kente / and hath that name Thanatos of deth of ≈øerpentes / for there ben none / And the erthe therof ≈øleeth ≈øerpentes yborn in to othir londes / There is noble corne londe and fruytfull / Hit is ≈øuppo≈øed that this Ilonde was balewed and ble≈ø≈øed of ≈øeynt Au≈øtyn the fir≈øt doctour of engli≈ø≈øhmen for there he arryued fir≈øt

div.head: Of the kyngis hye wayes and ≈øtretes. Capitulo ≈øeptimo.
div.p: MOliuncius kyng of Britons was the xxiij. of hem and the fir≈øt that yaf hem lawe / he ordeyned that plowmen ≈øolowes / goddes temples and heygh weyes that leden men to citees and tounes ≈øholde haue the fredom of ≈øocour / ≈øo that euery man that wente to ony of theÃÑ for ≈øocour or for tre≈øpaas that he had do / ≈øhold be ≈øauf for pour≈øute of all his enemyes / But afterward for the weyes were vncertayn & ≈øtrif was had / Therfor Belinus the kyng that was the for≈øaid Moliuncius ≈øone for to put away all doubte and ≈øtrif / made foure hyghe kynges weyes priueleged with all priuelege and fredome / And the weyes ≈øtretche thurgh the Ilonde / The fir≈øt & grete≈øe of the foure weyes is called fo≈ø≈øe / & ≈øtretcheth oute of the ≈øouth in to the north / and begynneth from the corner of cornewaille & pa≈ø≈øeth forth by deuen≈øhyre by ≈øomer≈øete & forth be≈øides Tetbury vpon Cotte≈øwold be≈øide couentre vnto Leyce≈øtre & ≈øo foth by wylde pleynes toward newerke & ended at lincoln / The ≈øeconde chief kynges high waye is named watling≈øtrete & ≈øtretcheth thwert ouer fo≈ø≈øe oute of the ≈øouthee≈øt in to the northwe≈øt / & begynneth at douer & pa≈ø≈øeth by the myddell of ken'te ouer tein≈øe be≈øide london by we≈øt we≈øtme≈øtre & ≈øo forth by ≈øeint Albon in the we≈øt ≈øide by don≈øtaple by ≈øtratford by towcetre by wedon by ≈øouth lylleborn / by atheri≈øton vnto Gilbertes hille that now is called wrekene & forth by ≈øeuarn & pa≈ø≈øeth be≈øides wrokce≈øtre & then forth to ≈øtratton & ≈øo forth by the myddell of wales vnto Cardykan and endeth atte Iri≈ø≈øh ≈øee / The thirde way is called Erynnuge≈øtrete and ≈øtretcheth oute of the we≈øt norwe≈øte in to ee≈øt ≈øouthe≈øt and begynneth in meneuia that is in ≈øeint dauids londe in we≈øte wales and ≈øtretcheth forth vnto ≈øouthampton / The fourthe is called Ryken ylde≈øtrete & ≈øtretcheth forth by worche≈øtre by wycombe by byrmyngeham by lichefeld by derby by che≈øtrefeld by yorke & forth vnto tynmouthe

div.head: ¬∂ Of famous Ryuers and ≈øtremes Ca. viij
div.p:
THre famous riuers rennen thurgh Britayn by ye whiche thre Ryuers marchaunts of beyonde the ≈øee comen in ≈øhippes in to Britayne well neyh oute of alle maner of nacions and londes / The≈øe thre Ryuers ben Tem≈øe / Seuarn and huÃÑ bre / The ≈øee ebbeth and floweth atte mouthes of the≈øe thre Ryuers and departeth the thre prouynces of the Ilonde as it were the thre kyngdomes a≈øondre / The thre parties ben / loegria / Cambria and
Northumbria / that ben middell englond / wales and northnmberland / R / The≈øe name tem≈øe ≈øemeth made one name of two names of two riuers that ben tame and y≈øe / for the riuer tame renneth be≈øides dorche≈øtre and falleth in y≈øe / therfore alle the riuer fro the fyr≈øt hede vnto the ee≈øt ≈øee is named Tamy≈øe or tem≈øe / Tem≈øe begynneth be≈øides tetbury that is thre myle bynorth malme≈øburx / There the tem≈øe ≈øpringeth of a welle that renneth ce≈øtward and pa≈ø≈øeth the fo≈ø≈øe and departeth Glouce≈øtre ≈øhyre / and wyl≈øhyre / and draweth with hym many othir welles and ≈øtreemes and wexeth grete at grece≈øtre and pa≈ø≈øeth forth than toward hampton and ≈øo forth by Oxenford by wallyngford by redyng and by london / Wilhelmus de ponÃÑ. ca. ij. Atte hauene of Sandwhiche hit falleth in to the ee≈øt ≈øee / and holdeth his name fourty myle beyonde london / and depar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d in ≈øomplace kente and e≈ø≈øex we≈øt≈øex and mercia that is as it were a grete-dele of middell englond / R / Seuarne is a riuer of Batayne and is called habern in britone and hath that name habern / of habren that was E≈øtrildes doughter / GueÃÑdolon the quene drenched this habren therin / therfor the britons called the riuer babren after the woman that was drowned therin / but by corrupt latyn it is called ≈øabrina Seuarn in engli≈øh Seuarn begynneth in the myddell of wales & pa≈ø≈øed fir≈øt toward the ee≈øt vnto ≈øhrowe≈øbury / and thenne torneth ≈øouthward vnto briggenorth wirce≈øtre and glouce≈øtre and falleth in to the we≈øt ≈øee be≈øides bri≈øtowe and departed in ≈øomme place englond and wales Wilhel. de ponÃÑ. li. iiij. Seuarn is ≈øwyft of ≈øtreme / fi≈ø≈øhe craft is ther in / wodenes of the ≈øwolewynge and of whirlyng water ca≈øteth vp & gadrith to hepe grete hepes of grauel / Seuarn ofte ari≈øeth & ouerflowrth the bankes / R / Humbre hath that name of humbre kyng of hunes for he was drowned therin And renneth fyr≈øt a crook oute of the ≈øouth≈øide of york / and thenne it departed the prouynce of lynde≈øeye that longed ≈øomtyme to the merces from-the othir contrey northumberland / Trente and ou≈øe rennen in to humbre and maken the riuer full grete Treui≈øa / The merces were men as it were of myddell englond as it ≈øhall be ≈øaid here after

div.head: ¬∂ Of auncient citees and tounes Ca. ix.
div.p:
THe kyngdome of britayne was ≈øomtyme made fair with xxviij. noble citees withoute right many ca≈øtels y‚Ä¢ were walled with toures with yates & with barres ≈øtrongly buylded / Alf ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . The≈øe were the names of the citees / ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lud that is
london / Caerbranc / that is yorke / Caerkente / that is Caunterbury / Caergoraugon that is wirce≈øtre / Caerlirion that is leyce≈øtre / Caerclon that is Glouce≈øtre / Caercolden that is Colche≈øtre / Carrei that is Chiche≈øtre / Saxons called it ≈øomtyme Ci≈ø≈øonce≈øtre / Caerceri that is C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ce≈øtre / Caerguent that is wynche≈øtre / Caergraunte / that is Cambrygge / Caerleyll that is luguba ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a and Krarlyll / Caerperis that is porche≈øtre / Caerdrom that is dorche≈øtre Caerludcoit that is lincoln and lindecolin Ca ‚Ä¢ rmerthyn that is merlins cite / Caer≈øegent that is ≈øice≈øtre and is vpon Tem≈øe not fer from R ‚Ä¢
dyng / Caerthleon that is Caerlegion al≈øo and hight fir≈øt leg ‚Ä¢ ce≈øtre and now is named Che≈øtre Caerbathon that is Bathe and hightr ≈øommetyme Athamannus Cyte / Caerpaladour that is ≈øepton that no whighte Shafte≈øbury / R / Other citees hen founden in cronyks for vnder≈øtondyng of ≈øtoryes / of whom it ≈øhall folowe / Wilhel. de ponÃÑ. London is a riall and a riche Cite vpon Tamy≈øe / of burgey≈ø≈øes of riche≈ø≈øes of marchaunts of chaffare and of marchandy≈øe / Therfore it is that ≈øomtyme whan derth of vitails is in all Englond commuly at london it is be≈øt chepe becau≈øe of the byars and ≈øellars that be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ at london / Gaufre. Brute the fir≈øt kyng of Batons buylded and edefied this Cyte of london the fir≈øt cite of Britayne in remeinbraunce of the Cyte of Troye that was de≈øtroyed and called it Troyene weth and trinouantum that is new Troye / Afterward kyng lud called it Caerlud after his owne name / therfor Britons hadde grete indignacion as Gildas telleth / Afterward Engli≈ø≈øhmen called the Cyte london / and yet after that Normans called it loundres / and is named in latyn londonia / Rudhudibras kyng ‚Ä¢ eyles ≈øone was the viij. kyng of Britons / he bylded Caunterbury the chief Cite of kente / and called it Caerkente / Afterward engli≈ø≈øhmen called it dorobernia / but that is not douer that ≈øtondeth vpon y‚Ä¢ clyf of the Fren≈ø≈øhe ≈øee And is from this douer xij. Engli≈ø≈øh myle / Afterward this dorobernia was and is called Caunterbury / The ≈øame kyng Rudhudibras buylded wynche≈øtre and called it Caerguent / And after Engli≈ø≈øhmen called it wente and wynche≈øtre after the name of one wyne an Engli≈ø≈øhman that was bi≈ø≈øhopp there / all we≈øt ≈øaxon was ≈øubgrtte to hym / the ≈øame kyng bylded palodour that is S ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ on / that now is called Shafte≈øbury / Britons tellen that an Egle prop ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cied there ≈øomtyme / Bladud beyles ≈øone a nigro man ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r was the ix. kyng of Britons / he bylded Bathe & called it Caerbadun / Engli≈ø≈øhmen called it after Athamannes cite / but
atte la≈øt men called it bathonia that is bathe / wil ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l. de ponÃÑ. li. ij. In this cite welleth vp and ≈øpringeth hote bathes and men wene that Iulius cezar made there ≈øuche bathes / R / But Gaufe ‚Ä¢ . mone muten≈øis in his britons book ≈øeyth that Bladud made ‚Ä¢ hilke bathes becau≈øe that william hath not ≈øeen that britons book wrote ≈øo by tellyng of othir men / or by his owne g ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øing as he wrote othir thinges not be≈øt aui≈øedly / Therfore it ≈øemeth more ≈øothly that bladud made not the hote bathes / n ‚Ä¢ Iulius cezar dide ≈øuche a dede though bladud bilde and made the cyte / but it accordeth better to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ endly re≈øon that the water renneth in the erthe by veynes of b ‚Ä¢ y m≈ø ‚Ä¢ on and ≈øulphur and ≈øo is kendly made ‚Ä¢ oot ‚Ä¢ in that cours & ≈øpringeth vp in diuer≈øe places of the cite / And ≈øo ther ben ‚Ä¢ oot bathes that wa≈ø≈øheth of tetres foores and ≈økabbis / Treui≈øa / Though men myght by craft make hote bathes for to dure longe y nough this accordeth well to re≈øon and to philo≈øophye that treteth of hote welles and bathes that ben in diuer≈øe londes though the water of this bath be more trobly and ≈øourer of ≈øauour and of ≈ømelle than othir hote bathes ben that I haue ≈øeen at akon in Almayn And at Eyges in ≈øauoye / whiche ben fair and clere as ony cold welle ≈øtreme / I haue ben bathed therin and a≈ø≈øayed them / R / Claudius cezar maried his doughter to Aruiragus kyng of britons / This Claudius cezar bilded glouce≈øtre in the weddyng of his doughter Britons called this cite fir≈øt after ClaudiÍù∞ name / but afterward hit was called glouc ‚Ä¢ ≈øtre after one glora / which was duke of that contrey / and ≈øtondeth vpon ≈øeuarn in the marche of Englond and wales / Shrowe≈øbury is a cite vpon ≈øeuarne in the marche of englond and wales. y ≈øette vpon the toppe of an hylle / And it is called ≈øhrowe≈øbury of ≈øhrobles and fruyt that grewe there ≈øomtyme on that hille / Britons cleped it ≈øomtyme pengwern / that is the hede of a faire tree / Shrowe≈øbury was ≈øomtyme the hede of powe≈øie that ≈øtretcheth forth thwert ouer the myddell of wales vnto the Iu≈ø≈øh ≈øee / Notyngham ≈øtondeth vpon trente and ≈øomtyme heet Snotyngham that is the wonnyng of dennes for the danes duel
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d there ≈øomtyme and dygged dennes and caues vnder hard ≈øtones and rockes and dnelled there / R / Lyncoln is chief of the prouynce of lynde≈øaye / and was callid ≈øomtyme Caerludcoyt / & afterward lyndeoolyn / It is vncerteyn who bilded fir≈øt this cite but yf it were kyng lud / and ≈øo it ≈øemeth by menyng of the name / for Caer is briti≈ø≈øh aud is to ≈øaye a cite and coyt is a wode / and ≈øo it ≈øemeth that Caerludcoyt is to ≈øaye luddes wode tounekyng
‚Ä¢ dgar come thider ≈øomtyme with vij. kynges y‚Ä¢ were ≈øubget to him A metrer breketh out in this maner in pray≈øing of this cite / Cle≈øtre ca≈øtell toune as it were / name taketh of a ca≈øtell / It is vnknowe what man bild this cite now / Tho begece≈øtria chees / hete now toune of legiones / Now wal≈ø≈øh and engli≈ø≈øh, holde this toune of grete pris / Stones on walle / ≈øemeth werke hercu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s all / ther longe with myght / to dure that hepe is y hight / Saxon ≈ømall ≈øtones / ≈øette vpon grete ben attones / Ther vnder grounde / lotyng double vout is founde / that helpeth with ≈øondes / many men of we≈øtern londes / Fy≈ø≈øh fle≈ø≈øh and corne low / this cite toun hath y now / ≈øhippes and chaffare / ≈øee water bringeth ynough thare / Gode≈øtalle ther is / that was Emperour er this / And ferth henry kyng / erthe is there righten duellyng / Of kyng haralde / pouder is ther yet y halde / Bachus and mercurius / Mars and venus / al≈øo lauerna / Protheus and pluto regnen there in the toune / Treui≈øa / God wote what this is to mene / but poetes in her maner of ≈øpeche feynen as though euery kynde craft and lyuyng had a diuer≈øe god euerich from othir / And ≈øo they feyned a god of bataill and of fighting and callid hym mars / and a god of coueti≈øe of riche≈ø≈øe and marchandi≈øe / and called hym mercurius And ≈øo bachus he called god of wyn / Venus godde≈ø≈øe of loue and beaute / lauerna god of thefte and of robberye Protheus god of fal≈øhede and of gyle and Pluto god of helle / And ≈øo it ≈øemeth that the≈øe ver≈øes wold mene / that the≈øe for≈øaid goddes regne and ben ≈øerued in che≈øtre / Mars with fyghtyng and cokkyng / Mercurius with coueti≈øe of riche≈ø≈øe and marchandy≈øe / Bachus with grete drynkyng / Venus with loue lewdly / Lauerna with theft and robberye / Protheus with fal≈øhe de and gyle / Thenne is Pluto not vn≈øerued god of helle / R / Ther babilon lore more myght hath trouthe the more

div.head: Of prouynces and ≈øhyres Ca. x.
div.p:
TAke hede that englond contryneth xxxij. ≈øhyres and prouynces that now ben called erldoms re≈øerued Cornewayle & the Ilondes Alfre. The≈øe ben the names of the erldom & ≈øhires / Kente South≈øex Sotherey Hamp≈øhire Barok≈øhire that hath his name of a bare ook that is in the fore≈øt of wynde≈øore / for at that bare ook / men of that ≈øhire were wonte come to ged ‚Ä¢ es and make theyr tretis / & there take counceyll & aduys / Al≈øo wyld≈øhyre that heet ≈øomtyme the prouynce of Semeran / Somer≈øete / Dor≈øete Deuen≈øhyre that now is called Deuonia in latin / The≈øe ix. ≈øouth≈øhyres the Tamy≈øe departed from the othir dele of englond whiche
were ≈øomtyme gouerned and reuled by the we≈øt≈øayons lawe / Ee≈øt≈øex myddel≈øex ≈øouthfolk northfolk hertford≈øhyre huntingdon ≈øhyre Northampton ≈øhyre Cambrigge≈øhyre / Bedford≈øhire Buykyngham≈øhire Leyce≈øtre≈øhire Derby≈øhire Notingham ≈øhire Lyncoln≈øhire Yorke≈øhire Durham≈øhire Northumberland Caerleyl≈øhire with Cumberlond Appelby≈øhire with we≈øtmerlond / Lanca≈øter≈øhire that conteyneth fyne litell ≈øhires / The≈øe xv. north and Ee≈øt≈øhires were ≈øomtyme gouerned and reuled by that lawe whiche is called danelawe But Oxenford ≈øhire warwyk≈øhire glouce≈øtre≈øhire wirce≈øtre≈øhire herford≈øhire ≈øhrop≈øhire ≈øtafford≈øhire che≈øtre≈øhire The≈øe viij. myddell and we≈øt ≈øhires were ≈øomtyme gouerned and reuled by the lawe called Mercia in latin and merchene lawe in engli≈ø≈øh / It is to wete that york≈øhire ≈øtretcheth from the Ryuer of of humbre vnto the riuer of Tey≈øe / And yet in york≈øhire ben xxij. hondredis hundred and candred is all one / Candred is one word made of wal≈ø≈øh and Iri≈ø≈øh / and is to menyng a contrey that conteyneth an hondred touncs / and is al≈øo in engli≈ø≈øh called wepentak / for ≈øomtyme in the comyng of a new lord / tenauntes were wonte to yelde vp her wepen in ≈øtede of homage / Duram≈øhire ≈øtretcheth from the Ryuer Tey≈øe vnto the riuer of Tyne / And to ≈øpeke proprely of Northumberlond it ≈øtretcheth fro the riuer of Tyne vnto the riuer of Twede that is in the begynnyng of ≈øcotland / Then yf the contrey of Northumberland that was ≈øommetyme from humbre vnto twede be now acounted for one ≈øhire and one Erledome as it was ≈øommetyme / Thenne ben in Englond but xxxij. ≈øhires / but if the contre of Northumberland be departed in to vj. ≈øhires / that hen Euerwyk≈øhire Duram≈øhire Northumberlond Caerleyl≈øhire Appelby≈øhire and lanca≈ø≈øhire / Thenne ben in englond xxxvj. ≈øhires withoute Cornewayle and al≈øo withoute the Ilondes / Kyng william conquerour made alle the≈øe prouynces and ≈øhires to be de≈øcreued and moten / Thenne were founden xxxvj. ≈øhires and half a ≈øhire / Tounes two and fifty thou≈øand foure ≈øcore Pari≈ø≈øh chirches xlv. M. and two / Knyghtes fees lxxv. M. wherof men of religion haue xxviij. M. xv. knyghtes fees / But now woodes ben hewen doun and the londe newe tilled & made moche more than was at that tyme and many tounes and villages bylded / and ≈øo ther ben many mo villages and tounes now than were in that tyme / And where as afore is wreton that Cornewayle is not ≈øette among the ≈øhires of Englond / it may ≈øtonde among them well ynough / for it is neyther to wales neyther in
≈øcotland but is in englond and Ioyneth to deuen≈øhire And ≈øo may ther ben acompted in englond xxxvij. ≈øhires and an half with the othir ≈øhires.

div.head:
¬∂ De legibus legum
que vocabulis
div.p:
‚Ä¢ Vnwallo that heet Moliuncius al≈øo made fir≈øt lawes in Britayne the whiche lawes were calle moliuncius lawes / and were ≈øolempnly ob≈øerued vnto william conquerours tyme / Moliuncius ordeyned amonge his lawes / that citees temples and weyes that lede men therto / and plowmen ≈øolowes ≈øhold haue priuilege & fredome for to ≈øaue all men that wold flee therto for ≈øocour and refuge / Thenne afterward Marcia quene of britons that was gwytelinus wyf of her the prouynce had the name mercia as ≈øomme men ≈øuppo≈øe / She made a lawe full of right of wytte and of re≈øon / and was called merchene lawe / Gildas that wrote the hi≈øtories of britons torned the≈øe two lawes oute of briton ≈øpeche in to latin / And afterward kyng Aluredus torned all oute of latin in to Saxons ≈øpeche / and was called merchene lawe / Al≈øo the ≈øame kyng Aluredus wrote in engli≈ø≈øh and put to anothir lawe that heet we≈øt≈øaxon lawe Thenne afterward danes were lordes in this londe / and ≈øo come forth the thirde lawe that heet dane lawe / Of the≈øe thre lawes ≈øeint Edward the thirde made one commune lawe that yet is called ≈øeint Edwardes lawe I holde it well done to write here and expoune many termes of the≈øe lawes / Myndebruche / hurting of honour and wor≈øhipp / In fren≈ø≈øh bhe≈øchur dhonnour / Burbrucg in fren≈ø≈øh ble≈øchur de court ou de cloys / Grithbruch brekyng of pees / My≈økennyng changing of ≈øpeche in court / ≈øhewyng ≈øettyng forth of marchandi≈øe in fren≈øh Di≈øp ‚Ä¢ oier de marchandy≈øe / Ham≈øokne or hamfare a re≈øe made in ‚Ä¢ ous / for≈øtallyng wrong or lette don in the kynges hye waye / frith ≈øoken / ≈øewrte in defence / Sak forfait Soka / ≈øute of court / and ther of cometh / ≈øoken / Theam / ≈øute of bondmen fyghtyngwyte Amer≈øement for fyghtyng / Blodewyte / Mer≈øement for ≈øhedyng of blode ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ itwyte / amendes for chidyng of blode Leirwyte / amendes for lyeng by a bonde woman Guliwite / amendes for tre≈øpas / Scot a gadryng to werke of bayllies / Hidage / taillage for hydes of londe / Danegheld tayllage yei ‚Ä¢ en to the danes / that was of euery bona taterre, that is euery oxe londe thre pens / A wepentak and an houndred is all one / For the contre of tounes were wont to gyue vp wepen in the comyng of a lord / Le≈øtage / cu≈øtome y chalengid
in chepiuges faires and ≈øtallage / cu≈øtome for ≈øtonding in ≈øtretes in feire tyme

div.head: ¬∂ Of kyngdome of boundes & merkis bitwene them Ca. xij
div.p:
THe kyngdome of britayne ≈øtode withoute departing hole & all one kyngdom to the britone from the fir≈øt brute vnto Iulius cezars tyme / and fro Iulius cezars tyme vnto Seuerus tyme this lond was vnder tribute to the romayns Netheles kynges they had of the ≈øame londe from ≈øeuerus vnto ye la≈øt prince gracian ≈øucce≈ø≈øours of britons failled & romayns regned in britayne / Afterward the romayns lefte of her regning in britayn becau≈øe it was fer from rome / & for grete be≈øine≈ø≈øe that they had in othir ≈øide / Then ≈øcottes & pictes by mi≈øleding of Maximus the tyraunt pur≈øiewed britayne & werred therin with grete ≈øtrengthe of men of armes longe tyme vnto the tyme that the ≈øaxons come atte praing of the britons ayen≈øt the pictes / & put oute Gurmonde the Iri≈ø≈øh kyng with his pictes & the britons al≈øo with her kyng that heet Careticus & drofe hem out of englond in to wales / & ≈øo the ≈øaxons were victours / & euery prouynce after his ≈øtrengthe made heÃÑ a kyng / And ≈øo departed englond in to vij. kyngdome Netheles afterward tho≈øe vij. kyngdoms euery after othir come alle in to one kyngdome all hool vnder the ‚Ä¢ nce adel≈øtone / Neuertheles the danes pour≈øued this lond fro Adelwolfis tyme that was Aluredes fader vnto the thirde ≈øeint Edwardes tyme about C. ixx. yere that regned therin continuelly xxx. yere After the danes the iij. ≈øeint Edward regned therin xxiij. yere & a litill more And after him harald helde the kyngdome ix. monethes / & after hem Normans haue regned vnto this tyme / But how longe they ≈øhall regne / he wote / to whom no thing is vnknowen / R / Of the for≈øaid vij. kyngdomes of her merkes meres and boundes whan they began & how longe they endured here ≈øhall I ≈øom what ≈øhortly telle / Alfre. The fir≈øte kyngdome was the kyngdome of kente / that ≈øtretcheth fro the ce≈øt Occean vnto the Fyuer of Tamy≈øe / There regned the fir≈øt hengi≈øtÍù∞ And began to regne by the acoÃÑpting of dioni≈øe the yere of our lord cccc. lv. that kyngdom dured ccc. lviij. yere vnder xv. kyngis vnto the tyme that baldrede was put out & egbert kyng of we≈øt≈øaxon Ioyned ye kyngdom to his owne The .ij. kyngdom was of ≈øouth≈øaxon yt had in the e≈øt ≈øide kente in the ≈øouth the ≈øee & the Ile of wyght in ye we≈øt haÃÑp≈øhire & in the north ≈øothery ther ella regned fir≈øt with
his thre ≈øones / And began to regne the yere after the comyng of the angles euen xxx. But that kyngdome within a ≈øhort tyme pa≈ø≈øed in to othir kyngdoms / The thrydde kyngdome was of ee≈øt≈øaxon / aud had in thee e≈øt ≈øyde the ≈øee / in the we≈øt the contrey of london / in the ≈øouth Tamy≈øe / in the north ≈øouthfolke / The kynges of this contrey e≈øt≈øaxon fro the fir≈øt ≈øebertes tyme vnto the tyme of the Danes were ten kynges whiche were ≈øubget ≈øomdell to othir kyngis / Netheles ofte≈øt and lenge≈øt they were vnder the kyngis of Mercia / and vnto that tyme that Egbert kyng of we≈øt≈øaxon Ioyned that kyngdome to his owne / The fourthe kyngdome was of ee≈øt anglis and conteyned Norffolk and ≈øuffolk / and had in the Ee≈øt ≈øyde and in the north the ≈øee / in the northwe≈øt Cambrige≈øhyre / in the we≈øt ≈øeint Edmondes dyche and herford≈øhire / And in the ≈øouth E≈øt≈øex / This kyngdome dured vnder twelue kyngis vnto the tyme that kyng Edmond was ≈ølayne / And thenne the danes toke wrongfully bothe the kyngdoms of ee≈øt anglis and of Ee≈øt≈øaxon / Afterward the danes were putte and driuen away or made ≈øubgette / And the elder kyng Edward Ioyned bothe the kyngdoms to his owne / The fyfthe kyngdome was of we≈øt≈øaxon and dured lenge≈øt of all the≈øe kyngdomes / and had in the ee≈øt ≈øide ≈øonth≈øaxon / in the north Tamy≈øe / in the ≈øouth and we≈øt the ≈øee Oxcean / In that kyngdome regned Serdrik with his ≈øone kenryk and began to regne the yere of our lord. v. C. xix. and after the comyng of angles lxxj. ≈øo ≈øeyth denys the othir kyngdomes pa≈ø≈øed in to this kyngdome / The ≈øixte kyngdome was of mercia and was grette≈øt of all / The markis and the meres therof were in the we≈øt ≈øide the riner dee fa≈øt by Che≈øtre and ≈øeuarn fa≈øt by Shrowe≈øbury vnto Bri≈øtowe in the e≈øte / the ee≈øt ≈øee / in the ≈øouth Tamy≈øe vnto london / In the north the riuer humbre And ≈øo we≈øtward and douneward vnto the riuer mer≈øee vnto the corner of wirhall / there humbre falleth in to the we≈øt ≈øee / Penda wibbes ≈øone regned fir≈øt in this kyngdome / in the yere of our lord Ihe≈øu cri≈øt vj. C. xxvj. ≈øo ≈øeyth denys / And fro the comyng of angles an C. lxxv. yere / This kyngdome dured vnder xviij. kynges aboute cc. lxiij. yere vnto the la≈øte Colwulf / to the whiche Colwulf the danes betoke that kyngdome to kepe / whan Burdred the kyng was putte oute / but the elder Edward the kyng put out the danes & Joyned the kyngdome of mercia to his owne kyngdome Netheles atte beginnyng this kyngdome of mercia was de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rted in thre in we≈øt mercia / in myddell mercia & e≈øt mercia The vij. kyngdom was
Northambimbror ‚Ä¢ that is the kyngdome of Northumberlond / the meres and markes therof were by we≈øt & by ee≈øt the ≈øee of Occean by ≈øouth the Ryuer of humbre and ≈øo douneward toward the we≈øt by thendes of the ≈øhires of notingham & of derby vnto the riuer of Mer≈øee / & by north the ≈øcotti≈ø≈øh ≈øee / that heet forthe in ≈øcotti≈ø≈øh / weris in briti≈ø≈øh / the ≈øcotti≈ø≈øh ≈øee in engli≈ø≈øh / This kyngdome of Northumberland was fir≈øt deled in two prouynces / that one was the ≈øouth ≈øide & heet deyra / & that othir was the north ≈øide & heet brenicia / as it were two kyngdoms / And the riuer departed the≈øe two kyngdoms that tyme / for the kyngdome of deyra was from the Riuer of humber vnto the riuer of Tyne / The kyngdome of brenicia was fro tyne to the ≈øcotti≈ø≈øh ≈øee / And whan pictes duelled there as Beda ≈øaith li. iij. ca. ij. that Ninian that holy man conuerted men of the ≈øouth ≈øide / I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the kyng regned there fir≈øt and began to regne the yere of our lord v. C. xlvij. ≈øo ≈øeith dyoni≈øe / In deyra regned kyng Elle the yere of our lord v. C. xlix. The≈øe two kyngdoms were othirwhile as it is ≈øaid departed bitwene ij. kynges & ≈øomtyme all hool vnder one kynge / and dured as it were xx. Engli≈ø≈øh kynges CCC. xxj. yere / Atte la≈øt O≈øburtus & Elle were ≈ølayne in the ix. yere of her kyngdome / the danes ≈ølowe hem / and Northumberlond was wyde withoute kyng viij. yere / Then afterward the danes regned in Northumberlond xxxvj. yere vnto the oonyng of the kyngdome Adel≈øtone / he made ≈øubgette the kynges danes ≈øcotti≈ø≈øh and wal≈ø≈øh / & regned fir≈øt allone in Englond and helde the kyngdome of englond all hool and all one kyngdome that was the yere of our lord v. ij. C. xxvij. That riuer of Mer≈øee was ≈øomtyme the marke and mere bitwene the kyngdome of mercia and the kyngdome of Northumberlond / that may be ≈øhewd in two maners / fir≈øt by the properte of this mer≈øee / that is as moche to ≈øaye as a ≈øee that is a bounde & a mere for it departeth one kyngdome from anothir / Al≈øo it is write in croniks of henry & of Alfrede / that kyng Edward the elder fa≈øtned a ca≈øtell at mamce≈øtre in Northumberlond / but that Cyte mamce≈øtre is fro the Ryuer of mer≈øee ≈øcarly. iij. myle

div.head: ¬∂ Of bi≈ø≈øhopriches and of their ≈øee ‚Ä¢ Ca. xiij
div.p:
Lucius was the fir≈øt kyng cri≈øtend of the britons / in his tyme were thre archebi≈ø≈øhops ≈øees in Britayne / one was at london / ‚Ä¢ nothir at york / and the thirde at Caeru≈øk the
Cyte of legions in glamergone / that Cyte now is called Carleon to the≈øe archebi≈ø≈øhops ≈øees were ≈øubgette xxviij. bi≈ø≈øhops and were called flammes / to the archebi≈ø≈øhops ≈øee of london was ≈øubgette Cornwaill & all myddell englond vnto humbre / To york all northhumberlond from the bowe of humbre with all ≈øcotlond / To Caerleon alle wales / ther were in wales vij. bi≈ø≈øhops & now ben but foure / Tho ≈øeuarne departed englond and wales / wilhel. de ponÃÑ. li. j. but in ≈øaxons tyme though ≈øeint gregorie had graunted london the priuerege of tharchebi≈ø≈øhops ≈øee Netheles ≈øeint Au≈øtyn yt was ≈øente in to englond by ≈øeint Gregorie torned tharchebi≈ø≈øhops ≈øee oute of london in to Caunterbury / After ≈øeint Gregories daye atte prayer of kyng athelbright and Citezeins and burgey≈øes of Caunterbury / there tharchebi≈ø≈øhops ≈øee hath dured vnto now ≈øaue that in the mene tyme Offa kyng of Mercia was wroth with men of Caunterbury / and benam hem that wor≈øhipp / and wor≈øhiped Adulph bi≈ø≈øhopp of lichfeld with the archebi≈ø≈øhops palle by a≈ø≈øente of Adrian the Pope vpon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ as by yeftes ≈øende / Netheles vnder kenulph the kyng it was re≈øtored to Caunterbury agayn The wor≈øhipp of the ≈øee of york hath dured there alway and dured yet though ≈øcotland be withdrawe fro his ≈øubiection by pa≈ø≈øing of tyme / Gir. in itinere libro primo / The archebi≈ø≈øhops ≈øee was ytorned oute of Ca ‚Ä¢ rleon in to Meneuia that is in the we≈øt ≈øide of de mecia vpon the Iri≈ø≈øh ≈øee in ≈øeint dauids tyme vnder kyng Arthur / From ≈øeint dauids tyme vnto ≈øamp≈øons tyme were in Meneuia archebi≈ø≈øhops xxiij. Afterward fyll a pe≈øtilence in all wales of the yelow euyll / that is called the Iaundis And then ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
≈øon the Archebi≈ø≈øhopp toke with him the palle and wente in to britayne Armonica the la≈ø≈øe Britayne and was there bi≈ø≈øhopp of do leu≈øis / From that tyme vnto the fir≈øt harryes tyme kyng of Englond were at meneuia which is called ≈øeint dauids xvj. bi≈ø≈øhops all without palle / whether it were for vnconnyng or for pouerte / Netheles alway fro that tyme the bi≈ø≈øhops of wales were ≈øacred of the bi≈ø≈øhopp of meneuia of ≈øeint dauies / & the bi≈ø≈øhop of meneuia was ≈øacred of the bi≈ø≈øhops of wales as of his ≈øuffrigans & made no profe≈ø≈øion ne ≈øubiection to none othir chirche / Other bi≈ø≈øhoppes that come afterward were ≈øacred at Caunterbury by compelling and hee≈øt of the kyng / in token of that ≈øacryng and ≈øubiection boneface archebi≈ø≈øhopp of Caunterbury that was legate of the cro≈ø≈øe ≈øonge in euery Cathedrall chirche of wales ≈øolempnly / Amas he was the fir≈øt archebi≈ø≈øhop of caunterbury that ≈øo dide in wales / &
that was done in the ≈øeconde harryes tyme / R / But now ben but two primates in all englond of caunterbury & of york / To the primate of Caunterbury ben ≈øubget xiij. bi≈ø≈øhops in englond & four in wales The primate of york hath but two ≈øuffrigans in englond that ben the bi≈ø≈øhops of Caerleyll and of durham / Of all the≈øe ≈øees and chaunyng of her places I ≈øhall ≈øhewe you hir folowyng Take hede in the begynnyng of holy chirche in englond bi≈ø≈øhops ordeyned their ≈øees in lowe places and ≈øimple that were couenable for contemplacion for prayers and deuocion / But in william coÃÑ querours tyme by dome of lawe Canon it was ordeyned that bi≈ø≈øhops ≈øhold come oute of ≈ømale tounes in to grete Citees / Therfor was the ≈øee of dorche≈øtre chaunged to lyncoln / lychfeld to che≈øtre Tetford to Norwych / Shirborn to Sali≈øbury / welles to Bathe / Cornwayll to Exe≈øtre / and ≈øele≈øey to Chiche≈øtre / The bi≈ø≈øhoppe of Roche≈øtre hath no pari≈ø≈øh but he is tharchebi≈ø≈øhops chapelayn of Caunterbury / Sith the ≈øee of Caunterbury was fir≈øt ordeyned by ≈øeint Au≈øtyn / it chaunged yet neuer his place / Chiche≈øtre hath vnder hym only ≈øouth≈øex and the Ile of wight / And had his ≈øee fir≈øt in ≈øele≈øey in the tyme of tharchebi≈ø≈øhopp Theodore / And the ≈øee dured there CCC. xxxiij. yere vnder xx. bi≈ø≈øhops fro the fir≈øt wil frede vnto the la≈øt ≈øtygande / atte commaundemeut of kyng williaÃÑ conqueroure chaunged the ≈øee fro ≈øele≈øey to Chiche≈øtre

div.head: ¬∂ De epi≈øcopis occidentalibus / Wilhelmus.
div.p:
HAue mynde that all the prouynce of we≈øt≈øaxon had alway one bi≈ø≈øhopp fro the begynnyng vnto Theodorus tyme / by graunt of kyng I≈ølo kyng of we≈øt≈øaxon the fir≈øt birinus ordeyned a ≈øee at dorche≈øtre that is a ≈øimple toune by ≈øouth Oxenford bi≈øide walingford bitwene the metyng to gedyr of tems & tame / whan birinÍù∞ was dede kenwal ‚Ä¢ us the kyng ordeyned a ≈øee at wynche≈øtre as his fadre had purpo≈øed / ther agilbert a freÃÑ≈øh man was fir≈øt bi≈ø≈øhopp of all the prouynce of we≈øt≈øaxon / fro that tyme the cite and the ≈øee of dorche≈øtre perteyned & longed to the prouynce of mercia / for that Cite ≈øtondeth within Tem≈øe / And the Tem≈øe departed bitwene mercia and we≈øt≈øaxon / After that agilbert was put oute of wynche≈øtre that tho hihte wynton / Ther waz there an engli≈ø≈øh bi≈ø≈øhopp there that was called wyne / Somme men ≈øuppo≈øe that the Cyte hath the name of this wyne / and is called wynche≈øtre / as it were wynes Cite / At the la≈øte he was put oute and after hym come Leutherius the for≈øaid Agelbertes
neuew / After leutherius bedda a while was bi≈ø≈øhopp there / whan he was dede Theodorus tharchebi≈ø≈øhopp ordeyned ij. bi≈ø≈øhops to the prouynce of we≈øt≈øaxon / Daniel at wynche≈øtre / to him were ≈øubgette two contreyes Sothery & ≈øouthamp≈øhire / Aldelme at ≈øhir born / to him were ≈øubgette ≈øix contreyes / Bark≈øhire wilt≈øhire ≈øomer≈øete dor≈øete≈øhire deuen≈øhire & Cornewayll / Treui≈øa / It ≈øemeth by this that we≈øt≈øaxon conteyned ≈øothery / ≈øouthamp≈øhire Bark≈øhire wilt≈øhire Somer≈øete≈øhire dor≈øete≈øhire deuen≈øhire and Cornewayll / Wilhel. Afterward in elder Edwardes tyme to the≈øe two ≈øees were ordeyned by commaundement of formo≈øus the pope thre othir ≈øees / At welles for ≈øomer≈øete / At kyrton for deuen≈øhire / & at ≈øeint germayn for cornewayll / Not full longe afterward the ≈øixte ≈øee was ≈øette at ramme≈øbury for wilt≈øhire Atte la≈øt by commaundement of kyng william conquerour all the≈øe ≈øees ≈øaue wynche≈øtre were torned & chaunged out of ≈ømall tounes in to grete citees for ≈øhirborn & Rame≈øbury were torned in to Sale≈øbury Now to that ≈øee is ≈øubgette Bark≈øhire wilt≈øhire & dor≈øete / The ≈øee of welles was torned to Bathe / therto is now ≈øubgette all ≈øomerte / The ≈øees of kyrton & of Cornewaill were chaunged to Exe≈øtre / therto is ≈øubgette deuen≈øhire & Cornwaill

div.p:

div.p:
AT york was don ≈øee for all the prouynce of Northumberlond / Paulinus helde fir≈øt that ≈øee and was ordeyned of the bi≈ø≈øhopp of caunterbury / and helde that ≈øee of york vij. yere. Afterward whan kyng Edwyn was ≈ølayne & thinges were di≈øtourbed / Paulinus wente thens by water way in to kent from whens he come fir≈øt & toke with him the palle / Wilhel. li. iij. And ≈øo the bi≈ø≈øhoprich of york cee≈øed xxx. yere / & the v≈øe of the palle ≈øeced there an C. xxv. yere vnto that Egbert the bi≈ø≈øhopp that was the kynges broder of the londe recouerid it by auctorite of the pope R / Whan ≈øeint O≈ø wald regned Aidanus a ≈øcot was bi≈ø≈øhopp in brenicia that is the north ≈øide of Northumberlond / after him Finianus / after hym Salmanus / Wilhel. vbi sÃÑ. Atte la≈øt he wente into ≈øcotlond with grete indignacion for wilfrede vndertoke him for he helde vnlawfully e≈øterday / xxx. yere after that Paulinus was gone from thens wilfride was made bi≈ø≈øhopp of york / Beda li. iiij. but while he duelled long in frauÃÑce aboute his ≈øacryng at excityng of quartadecimano
rum / that were they that helde e≈øterday the xiiij. day of the mone Chedde was y take oute of his Abbeye of le≈øting and wrongfully put oute in to the ≈øee of york by a≈ø≈øent of kyng O≈øwy / But thre yere afterward Theodorus tharchebi≈ø≈øhopp dyde hym a way and a≈ø≈øigned him to the prouynce of Mercia / and re≈øtored wilfred to the ≈øee of york / But after wilfrede by cau≈øe of wrath that was bitwene him and the kyng Egfrid was put out of his ≈øee by helpe of theodorus tharchebi≈ø≈øhopp that was corrupt with ≈øomme maner mede / this was done after that wilfred had ben bi≈ø≈øhopp of york ten yere / Thenne atte in≈øtaunce of the kyng / the odorus made bo≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bi≈ø≈øhopp of york / and Cumbert at hagu≈øtald chirche / and eata at lindeffar chirche that now is called haly Ilond in the Riuer of Twede / Aidanus founded fir≈øt the ≈øee / and Theodorus made Eadhedus bi≈ø≈øhopp of Repoune that was comen agayne oute of linde≈øaye / wilfrede had be Abbott of Repoun / Theodorus ≈øente TrunwynÍù∞ to the londe of pictes in thendes of englond fa≈øt by ≈øcotlond in a place that heet candida ca≈øa / & whiterne al≈øo / there ≈øeint Nynian a briton was fir≈øt foundour & doctor / But all the≈øe ≈øees outake yorke fayled litell and litell / For the ≈øee of candida ca≈øa that is Galewey that longed tho to Englong dured many yeres vnder ten bi≈ø≈øhops / vnto that it had no power by de≈øtroyng of the pictes / The ≈øees of hagu≈øtald and of lindeffar was ≈øommetyme all one vnder ix. bi≈ø≈øhops aboute foure ≈øcore yere and ten and dured vnto the comyng of the danes In that tyme vnder
hyngar and hubba Ardulf the bi≈ø≈øhopp yede longe aboute with ≈øeint Cuberts body vnto kyng Aluredes tyme kyng of we≈øt≈øaxon and the ≈øee of lyndeffar was ≈øette at kunege≈øtre that is called ku / nyngi≈øburgh al≈øo / that place is called now vbbe≈øford vpon twede / Atte la≈øt the yvij. yere of kyng Egbert kyng edgaris ≈øone that ≈øee was changed to durham / & ≈øeint Cuthbertes body was brou»ùt theder by the doyng of Edmond the bi≈ø≈øhop / and fro that tyme forward the ≈øee of hagu≈øtald & of lyndeffar failleth vtterly The fir≈øt kyng henry the ix. yere of his regne made the new ≈øee at Caerleyl

THe archebi≈ø≈øhopp of Caunterbury hath vnder hym xiij. bi≈ø≈øhops in englond and foure in wales. he hath roche≈øtre vnder hym & that ≈øee hath vnder him a Íùëte in kent allone London hath vnder hym e≈øt≈øex myddel≈øex and half herford≈øhyre / Chyche≈øtre hath vnder him ≈øouth≈øex & the Ile of wyght Wynche≈øtre hath vnder hym hamp≈øhyre & ≈øouthereye / Sale≈øbury hath vnder hym bark≈øhire wild≈øhire & dor≈øet / Exetre hath vnder hym deuen≈øhire and Cornewayll / Bathe hath vnder hym ≈øomer≈øete≈øhire allone / Wirce≈øtre hath vnder hym glouce≈øtre ≈øhire wirce≈øtre≈øhire & half warwyk≈øhire / Herforde hath vnder hym herford≈øhire & ≈øomme of ≈øhrop≈øhire / Che≈øtre is bi≈ø≈øhopp of couentre & of lychfeld / & hath vnder him che≈øtre≈øhire ≈øtafford≈øhire derbi≈øhire half warwyk≈øhire ≈øomme of ≈øhrop≈øhire / & ≈øomme of lanca≈øtre≈øhire fro the riner of mer≈øee vnto the riuer of ripyll / Lyncoln hath vnder hym the prouynces that ben bitwene Tamy≈øe and humbre that ben the ≈øhires of lyncoln of leyce≈øtre of northampton of huntyngdon of bedford of ‚Ä¢ okyngham of oxenford and half herdford≈øhire / Ely hath vnder hym Cambrige≈øhyre oute take merlonde / Northwyche hath vnder hym merlonde / Norffolk and Suffolk / Al≈øo tharchebi≈ø≈øhoppe of Counterbury hath foure ≈øuffrygans in wales that ben / Landaf / Seint Dauyes Bangor / and ≈øaynt A≈ø≈øaph / the archebi≈ø≈øhopp of york hath now but two bi≈ø≈øhops vnder hym that ben Durham and Caerleyll / R / And ≈øo ben but two primates in Englond / what one of hem ≈øhall doo to that othir and in what maner point he ≈øhall be obedient and vnder hym / It is fullx conteyned with Inne aboute the yere of our lord Ihe≈øu cri≈øt a. M. lxxij. to fore the fir≈øt kyng william / and the bi≈ø≈øhops of Englond by commaundeinent of the pope / the cau≈øe was handled and y treated bitwene the for≈øaid primates / and ordeyned and demed that the primate of york ≈øhall be ≈øubget to the primate of Cannterbury in thingis that longen to the wor≈øhip of god and to the beleue of holy chirche
therof / of the which ≈øeyth Beda li. iiij. ca. xj. that Sexnulfus was fir≈øt bi≈ø≈øhopp there. and Aruiragus were accorded and legyons of rome were ≈øente into Irlonde tho was Carleon a noble cite and of grete auctorite & by the romayns rially bild & walled aboute with walles of f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nt hye and riall to ≈øtonde and ≈øitte in / And to beholde aboute / the places were rially clo≈øed wtth riall walles that yet ≈øomdele ≈øtondeth right nyhecloos / And withinne the walles and withoute is londe in we≈øtwales In this Caerleon was Amphibalus y born that taught ≈øeint allone / There the me≈ø≈øagers of rome come to the grete Arthurs court yf it is ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ effull to trowe Treui≈øa / yf while he maketh non euidence / for in neyther ≈øide he telleth what moeueth him ≈øo for to ≈øaye / R / There is another cite of legions there his cronike was bytrauailled as it is clerly knowen by the
