Cyte is vnknowen / For who that ≈øeeth the foundements of the grete ≈øton ‚Ä¢ s wold rather wene that it were Romayns werke or werke of Gyantes / than it were made by ≈øettyng of Britons / This Cyte ≈øommetyme in briti≈ø≈øh ≈øpeche heet Carrthleon legece≈øtria in latin / and Che≈øtre in Engli≈ø≈øhe and the Cyte of legions al≈øo / For ther lay ‚Ä¢ a wyn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r the legions of knyghtes that Iulius cezar ≈øente for to „Äà‚óä„Äâ Irlonde / And after Claudius cezar ≈øente legions oute of that Cyte for to wynne the Ilondes that be called orcades / what euer william malme≈øbury by tellyng of othir men mette of this Cyte / This Cyte hath plente of lyuelode of corn of fle≈ø≈øh of fy≈ø≈øh / and ≈øpecially of pris of Samon / this Cyte re≈ø≈øeyueth grete marchaundy≈øe and ≈øendeth oute al≈øo / Al≈øo neyh this Cyte ben ≈øalt welles / Metall and oore / Northumbres de≈øtroyed this Cyte ≈øommetyme / But afterward Elfleda lady of Mercia buylded it attayne and made it moche more / In this ≈øame Cyte ben weyes vnder the er ‚Ä¢ he with vowtes and ≈øtonewerk wonderly y wrought thre chambred werkes grete ≈øtones y graue with old mennes names therin / Ther is al≈øo Iulius cezars name wonderly in ≈øtones y graue and othir noble mennes al≈øo with the writing aboute / This is the Cyte that Ethelfryd kyng of Northumberland de≈øtroyed / and ≈ølough there fa≈øte by neyh two thou≈øand monkes of the myn≈øter of Bang ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ / ¬∂ This is the Cyte that
≈øo that in what place euer it be in englond that the primate of cannterbury wyll hote & con≈øtreyne to gader a coun≈øeill of clergie / the pmate of yorke is holden with his ≈øuffrigans for to be „Äà‚óä„Äâ & for to be obedient to the ordinauÃÑce that there ≈øhall lawfully be ordeyned whan the primate of Caunterbury is dede / the pmate of york ≈øhall come to Caunterbury & with othir bi≈ø≈øhops he ≈øhall ≈øacre him that is cho≈øen / & ≈øo with othir bi≈ø≈øhoppes he ≈øhall ≈øacre his owne primate yf the primate of york he dede / his ≈øucce≈ø≈øour ≈øhall come to the bi≈øhop of Caunterbury & he ≈øhall take his ordenaunce of him & doo his ooth with Íùìfe≈ø≈øion & lawfull obedience / After within aboute the yere of our lord xj. C. lxxxxv. in the tyme of kyng Rychard ben re≈øons ≈øette for the right of the partie for eyther primate / and what one primate dyde to that othir in tyme of Thur≈øtinÍù∞ of Thomas & of othir bi≈ø≈øhops of york from the conque≈øt vnto kyng harries tyme the thirde / Al≈øo there it is ≈øaid how eche of them ≈øtarte from othir / This place is but a for≈øpekyng & not a full tretis therof / Therfore it were noyefull to charge this place with all thilke re≈øons that there ben made

div.head: ¬∂ Of how many maner peple hath duellid therin C ‚Ä¢ . xiiij
div.p:
BRytons duelled fir≈øt in this Ilonde the xviij. yere of hely the Íùìphete / the xj. yere of Soluius po≈øthumus kyng of latins / xliij. yere after the takyng of Troye / to fore the byldyng of rome CCCC. xxxij. yere. Beda li. j. They come heder and toke her cours from Armorik that now is that oth ‚Ä¢ r britayn / they helde longe tyme the ≈øouth contreyes of the Ilonde / hit befell afterward in va≈øpa≈øianus tyme duke of Rome / that the pictes ≈øhipped out of ≈øcicia in to Occean / & were driuen aboute with the wynde & entred in to the north co≈øtes of Irlond & fonde there ≈øcottes and prayde to haue a place to duelle inne / & myght none gete / For Irlonde as ≈øcottes ≈øaide myght not ≈øu≈øteyne bothe peple / Scottes ≈øente the pictes to the north≈øides of Britayne / and behight them helpe ayen≈øt the Britons that were their enemyes yf they wolde ari≈øe / & toke hem wyues of her doughtres / vpon ≈øuche condicion yf doubt ‚Ä¢ fylle / who ≈øhold haue right for to be kyng / they ≈øhold rather che≈øe hem a kyng of the moder ≈øide / than of the fadre ≈øide / of the wy ‚Ä¢ men kyn rather than of the men kyn / Gaufre / In va≈øpa≈øian the Emperours tyme whan Marius Aruiragns ≈øone was kyng of britons One Rodryk kyng of pictes cam out of ≈øcicia and gan to
de≈øtroye ≈øcotland / thenne Marius the kyng ≈ølew this roderik and yaf the north partie of ≈øcotlande that heet Cat ‚Ä¢ ene≈øia to the men y‚Ä¢ were come with roderik and were ouercome by hym for to duelle Inne / But the≈øe men had no wyues ne none myght haue of the nacion of britons / therfor they ≈øailled in to Irlande & toke to theyr wyues Iri≈ø≈øhmens doughtres by that couenaunt that the moder blode ≈øhold be put to fore in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of heritage / Gir. ca. xvij. Netheles Sirinus ≈øuÍùë Virgi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uÃÑ ≈øeyth that pictes ben agatir≈øes that had ≈øomme duellyng place aboute the waters of Scicia / and they ben called pictes of peynting and ≈ømyting of woundes that ben ≈øene on her body / So that they ≈øemed as men were peynted with woundes therfore they were called pictes as peynted men / The≈øe men and the≈øe gothes ben all one peple / For whan Maximus the tyrant was wente oute of britayne in to fraunce for to ocupye theÃÑ pire / Thenne gracianus and valentinianus that were bretheren & felaws of thempyre bronght the≈øe gothes oute of Scicia with grete yeftes with flateryng and fayre ‚Ä¢ ehe≈øtes in to the northcontrey of britayne / For they were ≈øtal worth and ≈øtronge men of armes / And ≈øo the≈øe theuys & ‚Ä¢ ribours were made men of londe & of contre and duelled in the north contreyes and helde there cites & tounes Gaufre. Carancius the tyrant ≈ølowe ba≈ø≈øianus by helpe and tre≈øon of the pictes that come in helpe and ≈øocour of ba≈ø≈øianus / and yaf the pictes a duellyng place in albania that is ≈øcotlande / there they duelled longe tyme afterward y medled with britons R / Thenne ≈øith that pictes ocupied fir≈øt the north ≈øide of ≈øcotlonde It ≈øemeth that the duellyng place that this Caran≈ø ‚Ä¢ us yaf hem is the ≈øouth ≈øide of ≈øcotlande that ≈øtretcheth from the thwert ouer wall of romayns werk to the ≈øcotty≈ø≈øh ≈øee / and conteyneth Galleway and lodouia that is lodeway / Therof Beda li. iij. ca. ij. ≈øpeketh in this maner / Nynyan the holy man conuerted the ≈øouth pictes / Afterward the Saxons come and made that contrey longe to bremcia the north partie of Northumberland / vnto the tyme that kynadiÍù∞ Alpinus ≈øone kyng of ≈øcotland put oute the pictes / and made that contrey that lyeth bitwene twede and the ≈øcotty≈ø≈øh ≈øee longe to his kyngdome / Beda li. j. c ‚Ä¢ . j. Afterward longe tyme the ≈øcottes were led by duke renda / and come oute of Irlonde that is the propre contrey of ≈øcottes and with loue or with ≈øtrength made hem a place fa≈øt by the pictes in the north≈øide of that arme of the ≈øee / that breketh in to the londe in the we≈øt ≈øide that departed in olde tyme bitwene britons and pictes / Of this duke kend ‚Ä¢ the ≈øcottes
had the name and were called dalrendines as it were Rendaes part / For in hir ≈øpeche a part is called dal / Gir. pÃÑ. the pictes might haue no wyues of britons / but they toke hem wyues of Iri≈ø≈øh ≈øcottes and promy≈øed hem fair for to duelle with hem / and graunted hem a londe by the ≈øee ≈øyde / there the ≈øee is narow / that londe is called now Gallewaye / Marianus / Iri≈ø≈øh ≈øcottes londed at argayll that is ≈øcottyn clif for ≈øcottes londed there for to doo harme to the britons / or for that place is next to Irlonde for to come a londe in to Britayne / Beda / And ≈øo the ≈øcottes after the britons and pictes made the thirde peple duellyng in britayne / R / Thenne after that come the ≈øaxons atte prayng of the britons / to helpe hem ayen≈øt the ≈øcottes and pictes / And the britons were ≈øone put oute in to wales / and ≈øaxons ocupied the londe lytill and litill / and efte more to the ≈øcotty≈ø≈øh ≈øee / And ≈øo ≈øaxons made the fourthe maner of men in the Ilonde of britayn / Beda li. v. ca. ix. For ≈øaxons and angles come oute of Germania / yet ≈øomme britons that duellen nygh calle hem ≈øhortly germans / R / Netheles aboute the yere of our lord viij. C. Egbertus kyng of we≈øt≈øaxon commaunded and badde all men to calle the men of the londe engli≈ø≈øhmen / Alfre. Thenne after that the danes pur≈øued the londe aboute a cc. yere / that is for to ≈øay fro the for≈øaid Egbertes tyme / vnto ≈øeint Edwardes tyme / & made the fyfthe maner of peple in the Ilonde / but they faylled afterward / Atte la≈øt come normans vnder duke william and ≈øubdued engli≈ø≈øhmen / and yet kepe they the londe / and they made the ≈øixte peple in the Ilonde / But in the fir≈øt kyng harryes tyme come many flemynges and receyued a duellyng place for a tyme be≈øide maylros in the we≈øt ≈øide of englond / and made the ≈øeuenthe peple in the Ilonde / Netheles by commaundement of the ≈øame kyng they were put thennes and driurn to hauerfordes ≈øide in the we≈øt ≈øide of wales / R / And ≈øo now in britayne danes and pictes fayllen all oute and fyue nacions duelle therin that ben ≈øcottes in Albania / that is ≈øcotland / Britons in Cambria / that is wales / but that flemynges duelle in that is we≈øt wales / And Normans and engli≈ø≈øhmen ben medled in all the Ilonde / for it is now doubte in ≈øtoryes how & in what maner they were put away & de≈øtroied oute of britayne / Now it is to declare how the pictes were de≈øtroied & faylled / Gir. pÃÑ. ca. xvij. Britayne was ≈øomtyme ocupied with ≈øaxons / & pees was made and ≈øtabli≈ø≈øhed with the pictes / thenne the ≈øcottes that come with the pictes ≈øaw that the pictes were nobler of dedes and better men of armes though they were la≈ø≈øe in nombre than the
≈øcottes / Thenne the ≈øcottes hauyng therof enuye torned to their naturell tre≈øon that they haue ofte
‚Ä¢ ≈øid / for in tre≈øon they pa≈ø≈øe othir men / and ben traitours as it were by kynde / for they prayde all the pictes ≈øpecially the grete of hem to a fe≈øte / & wayted her tyme whan the pictes were mery & had well dronke / they drewe vp nayles y‚Ä¢ helde vp holow benches vnder the pites and the pictes vnware & ≈øodenly fy ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in ouer the hamm ‚Ä¢ s in to a wondrefull pitfall / Thenne the ≈øcottes fyll on the pictes & ≈ølow hem & ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fte none alyue And ≈øo of two peple the better werriours were hooly de≈øtroyed / But the other that ben the ≈øcottes which ben traitours all vnlike to the pictes toke proffyte by that fals tre≈øon / for they toke all that londe & holde it yet vnto this tyme and calle it ≈øcotland after hir owne name / In kyng Edgarus tyme kynadius a≈øpinns ≈øone was duke and leder of the ≈øcottes & werred in picte londe & de≈øtroyed the pictes / he werred ≈øixe ≈øithes in ≈øaxon & toke all the londe that is bitwene twede & the ≈øcotti≈ø≈øh ≈øee with wronge & with ≈øtrength ‚Ä¢

div.head: ¬∂ Of the langages of maners and v≈øages of the peple of that londe Ca. xv
div.p:
AS it is knowen how many maner of peple ben in this IloÃÑ de ther ben al≈øo ≈øo many langages and tonges / Netheles wal≈ø≈øh & ≈øcottes that ben not medl ‚Ä¢ d with othir nacions kepe neyh yet their langage & ≈øpeche / But yet the ≈øcottes that were ≈øomtyme coÃÑfederate & duellid with pictes drawe ≈øomwhat aft their ≈øpeche But the fleÃÑmynges y‚Ä¢ duelle in the we≈øt ≈øide of wales haue lefte her ≈øtraung ‚Ä¢ ≈øpeche & ≈øpeken like to ≈øaxons / al≈øo engli≈ø≈øhmen though they had fro the beginnyng thre maner ≈øpeches / ≈øouthern / northern & myddell ≈øpeche in the myddell of the londe as they come of thre maner of peple of germania / Netheles by coÃÑmixtion and medling fir≈øt with Danes & afterward with Normans in many thinges the contre langage is appaired / for ≈øome v≈øe ≈øtrange wlaffing chitering harryng garryng & gri≈øbyting / This appayring of the langage cometh of two thinges / ones becau≈øe that children y‚Ä¢ gone to ≈øcole lerne to ≈øpeke fir≈øt engli≈ø≈øh / & than ben compellid to coÃÑ ≈øtrewe her le≈ø≈øons in fren≈ø≈øh & that haue ben v≈øed ≈øyn the normans com ‚Ä¢ in to englond / Al≈øo gentilmens children ben lerned & taught froÃÑ their yongth to ≈øpeke freÃÑ≈ø≈øh / & vp londi≈ø≈øh meÃÑ wyll couÃÑterfete & likene hem ≈øelfe to gentilmen / & arn be≈øy to ≈øpeke freÃÑ≈ø≈øh for to be more ≈øette by / wherfor it is ≈øaid by a comyn preerbe / Iack wold be a geÃÑtilmaÃÑ if he coude ≈øpeke freÃÑ≈ø≈øh / Cre. this was moche v≈øed to for y‚Ä¢
grete deth / but ≈øith it is ≈øomdele chaunged / for ≈øir Iohan Cornewayll a mai≈øter of gramer chaunged the techyng of gramer ≈øcole & con≈øtructton of fren≈ø≈øh in to engli≈ø≈øh And othir ≈øcolemaie≈øtrs v≈øe the ≈øame way now in the yere of our lord. M. CCC. lxxxv. the ix. yere of kyng Richard the ≈øeconde / & leue all fren≈ø≈øh in ≈øcoles & v≈øe alle con≈øtruction in engli≈ø≈øh / wherin they haue auantage one way that is that they lerne the ≈øonner their gramer And in anothir di≈øauauntage / for now they lerne no fren≈ø≈øh ne can none / whiche is hurte for them that ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe the ≈øee / And al≈øo gentilmen haue moche lefte to teche their children to ≈øpeke fren≈ø≈øh / R / Hit ≈øemeth a grete wonder that engli≈ø≈øh haue ≈øo grete duier≈øite in their owne laÃÑ gage in ≈øoune and in ≈øpekyng of it / whiche is all in one Ilonde / And the langage of normandie is comen oute of anothir lande / and hath one maner ≈øoune among alle them that ≈øpeketh it in englond / for a man of kente / Sonthern we≈øtern / & northern men ≈øpeken fren≈ø≈øh all lyke in ≈øoune & ≈øpeche / but they can not ≈øpeke theyr engli≈ø≈øh ≈øo / Creui≈øa / Netheles ther is as many diuer≈øe maner of fren≈ø≈øh in the reame of fraunce / as diuer≈øe engli≈ø≈øh in the reame of englond / R / Al≈øo of the for≈øaid tonge which is departed in thre is grete wonder / for men of the ee≈øt with men of the we≈øt accorde ‚Ä¢ et ‚Ä¢ in ≈øownyng of their ≈øpeche / than men of the north with men of the ≈øouth / Therfore it is that men of mercij that ben of myddell Englond as it were partiners with the endes / vnder≈øtande better the ≈øide langages northern & ≈øouthern than northern & ≈øouthern vnder≈øtande eyther othir / Wilhel. de ponÃÑ. li. iij. Alle the langages of the northumbres & ≈øpecially at york is ≈øo ≈øharp ≈øhittyng frotyng & vn≈øhappe / that we ≈øothern men may vnneth vnder≈øtande that langage / I ≈øuppo≈øe the cau≈øe be that they be nygh to the aliens that ≈øpeke ≈øtrangely / And al≈øo by cau≈øe that the kyngis of englond a byde and duelle more in the ≈øouth contrey / than in the north contre The cau≈øe why they abyde more in the ≈øouth contre than in y‚Ä¢ north contre / is by cau≈øe that ther is better corn londe more peple / moo noble Citees / & moo prouffytable hauenes in the ≈øouth contrey than in the north.

div.head: ¬∂ ‚Ä¢ e gentis huius moribus / Gir. in itinere
div.p:
FOr the maners and the doyng of wal≈ø≈øhmen and of ≈øcottes ben to fore ≈øom what declared / Now I purpo≈øe to tel „Äà‚óä„Äâ
and declare the maners and condicions of the medlyd peple of Englond / But the flemmynges that ben in the we≈øt ≈øyde of wales ben now all torned as they were Engli≈ø≈øhmen
becau≈øe they companye with engli≈ø≈øhmen / And they be myghty & ≈øtrong to fighte / and ben the mo≈øt enemyes that wali≈øhmen haue & v≈øe marchandy≈øe and clothyng and ben full redy to put hem ≈øelf to auentures and to perill in the ≈øee and londe becau≈øe of grete wynnyng / and ben redy ≈øommetyme to goo to the plow and ≈øomtyme to dedes of armes whan tyme and place axeth / It ≈øemeth of the≈øe men a grete wondre that in a boon of a wethers right ≈øholder whaÃÑ the f ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øh is ≈øoden away and not ro≈øted they knowe what haue be don / is don / & ≈øhall be don / as it were by a ≈øpirite of prophecie and a wonde full craft / They telle what is don in ferre contreyes / tokenes of pees or of werre / the ≈øtate of the royame / ≈øleyng of men / and ≈øpou≈øebreche ≈øuche thinges they declare certainly of tokenes and ≈øigne that is in ≈øuche a ≈øholdre boon / R / But the engli≈ø≈øhmen that duelle in englond ben medlid in the Ilonde and ben ferre fro the places that they ≈øpronge of fir≈øt / tornen to contrarie dedes lightly withoute enti≈øing of ony other men by her owne a≈ø≈øente / And ≈øo vne≈øy al≈øo full v ‚Ä¢ paciente of pees / enemye of be≈øines and full of ≈ølouthe / Wilhelmus de ponÃÑ. li. iij / ≈øeyth that whan they haue de≈øtroied her enemyes all to grounde / thenne they fighten with hem ≈øelfe and ≈øleeth eche othir / as a voyde and an empty ≈øtomak wircheth in hit ≈øelfe / R / Netheles men of the ≈øouth ben e≈øier and more mylde than men of the north / For they be more vn≈øtable more cruell and more vne≈øy / The myddell men ben ≈øommedele parteners with bothe / Al≈øo they v≈øe hem to glotonye more than othir men and ben more co≈øtlew in mete and clothyng / Me ≈øuppo≈øeth that they toke that v ‚Ä¢ ce of kyng Hardeknet that was a Done / For be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ te ≈øet he forth twyes deb ‚Ä¢ e me≈ø≈øe at diner & at ≈øoper al≈øo / Th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe men ben ≈øpedefull an hors & a fote / Able & redy to alle maner dedes of ar nes and ben wonte to haue victorye and mai≈øtrie in euery fight where no tre≈øon is walkyng and ben curious and can well telle dedes and wondres that they haue ≈øeyne / Al≈øo they gone in diuer≈øe lendes vnnethe ben ony men richer in her owne londe or more gracious in ferre and in ≈øtrange londe / they can better wynne and gete newe than kepe her owue heritage / Therfore it is that they be ≈øprad ≈øo wyde and wene that euery londe is theyr owne The men be able to all maner ≈øbeyght and wyttr / but to fore the dede blonderyng and ha≈øty / And more wy≈øe after the dede than to fore / and leuen of lyghtly what they haue begonne / Polinus. li. vj. Therfor Eugenius the pope ≈øaide that Engli≈ø≈øhmen were able to do what euer they wolde / and to be ≈øette and put tofore all othir
ne were that lyght wytte lettith / And as hanybal ≈øeyde that the Romayns myght not be ouercome / but in hir owne coutre / ≈øo Engli≈ø≈øhmen mow not be ouercome in ≈øtrange londes / but in hir owne contrey they be lightly ouercome / R / The≈øe men de≈øpi≈øen her owne / and pray≈øe othir mennys / And vnnethe ben ple≈øed ner apayd with their owne a≈øtate / what befalleth and becometh othir men / they wyll gladly take to hem ≈øelfe / Therfore it is that a yeman arayeth hym as a ≈øquyer / a ≈øquyer as a knyght / a knyght as a duke / a duke as a kyng / Yet ≈øomme goo aboute and wyll be like to all maner ≈øtate / and ben in no ≈øtate For they take euery degre that be of no degre / for in bering outeward they ben myn≈øtrals and berowdes / In talkyng grete ≈øpekers / In eting and drynkyng glotons / In gaderyng of catel huck≈øters and tauerners / In araye tormentours / In wynnyngis argi / In trauayll tantali / In takyng hede dedaly / In beddes ≈øardanapali / In chirches mametis In courtes thonder / only in pryuelege of clergy and in prebendes / they knowleche hem ≈øelfe clerkis / Treui≈øa. As touchyng the termes of latin as argi / tantali / dedali ≈øardanapali / ye mu≈øt vnder≈øtonde hem as the poetes feyned of them / Argus was an herde and kepte be≈øtes / be had an houndred eyen / And Argus was al≈øo a ≈øhip / a ≈øhipman and a chapman / And ≈øo Argus myght ≈øee before and behynde and on euery ≈øide / Therfore he that is wy≈øe and ware and can ≈øee that he be not deceyued / may be called Argus / And ≈øo the cronyke ≈øaith in plurel nombre / that engli≈ø≈øhmen ben argi / that is to ≈øaye they ≈øee aboute where as wynnyng is / That othir word tantali / the poete feyneth that Tantalus ≈ølowe his owne ≈øone / wherfore he is dampned to perpetuell penaunce / & he ≈øtandeth alway in water vp to the nether lyppe / and hath alway ripe apples and noble fruyt hangyng doune to the ouer lyppe / but the fruyt ne the water may not come within his mouth / he is ≈øo holde and ≈øtandeth bitwene mete and drynke and may neythir ete ne drynke / and is euer an hungrid and a thyr≈øt that wo is hym a lyue / by this maner lyknes of Tantalus / they that doo right nought there as moche is to doo in euery ≈øide ben called tantali / It ≈øemeth that it is to ≈øaye / In trauaylle they ben tantali / for they doo right nought therto / The thyrde word js dedali / Take hede that Dedalus was a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ btil and a ≈ølye man / And therfore by liknes they that ben ≈øubtyl and ≈ølye they be called dedali / The fourthe word is Sradanapali / Ye ≈øhall vnder≈øtande that Sardanapalus was kyng of A≈ø≈øiryens and was full vncha≈øt / & v≈øed
him to lye ≈øofte / And by a maner of likenes of him they that lyue vncha≈øtly ben y cleped ≈øardanapali / R / But among alle engli≈ø≈øh medlid to gedres is ≈øo grete chaunging & diuer≈øite of clothing & of aray & ≈øo many maners & diuer≈øe ≈øhappes / that well neyhe is ther ony man knowen by his clothing & his araye of what ≈øomeu degre that he be / Therof Íùìphecied an holy Anker in kyng Egelfredes tyme in this maner / Henri. li. vj. Engli≈ø≈øhmen for as moche as they v≈øe them to dronkelewnes / to tre≈øon & to reche ‚Ä¢ e≈ønes of goddes hous / fir≈øt by danes & thenne by normans / & atte thirde tyme by ≈øcottes that they hold mo≈øt wretches & le≈øt worth of all othir they ≈øhall be oucome Thenne ye world ≈øhall be ≈øo vn≈øtable & ≈øo diuer≈øe & variable that the vn≈øtablenes of thoughtes ≈øhall be bitokened by many maner diuer≈øitees of clothyng

div.head: ¬∂ Of the maner & ri≈øes of the wal≈ø≈øhmen Ca. xix.

lg.l: The maner lyuyng of ye londe

without lace & chaplet yt her lappes

to yeue a caudron with gruwele

div.head: ¬∂ Of the di≈øcripcion of Scotland Ca. xxj.
div.p:
HYt is a comyn ≈øaw that the contre which is now named ≈øcotland / is an out≈øtretchyng of the north Íùëtie of britayn & is deÍùëted in the ≈øouth ≈øide from britayne with armes of the ≈øee / Und in the othir ≈øide all aboute beclipped with the ≈øee / this londe heet ≈øomtyme albania / & had that name of albanactus / that was kyng brutus ≈øone / for albanactus duelled fir≈øt therin / or of the prouynce albania / that is a contre of Scicia & nygve to amazona / therfor ≈øcottes ben called as it were ≈øcittes / for they come out of Scicia / Afterward that londe beet pictauia for the pictes regned therin a thou≈øand yere lxx. or as ≈øomme telle a M. CCC. lx. yere. And atte la≈øt beet hibernia as Irlonde heybte / Gir. in top. For many ≈økyles / one ≈økyl is for affynite & alye / that was bitwene them & Iri≈ø≈øhmen / for they toke wyues of Irlond and that is openly ≈øeen in her bileue / in clothyng in langage & in ≈øpeche / in wepen & in maners / Anothir ≈økyl is for Iri≈ø≈øhmen duelled there ≈øomtyme Beda li. j. Oute of Irlonde that is the propre contrey of ≈øcottes come Iri≈ø≈øhmen with her duke that was called Renda / And with loue and with ≈øtrength made hem chief ≈øees aud citees be≈øides the pictes in the north≈øide / Gir. Now thee londe is ≈øhortly called Scotland of ≈øcottes that come oute of Irlonde & regned therin CCC. xv. yere vnto the rede williams tyme that was Malooline broder / R / Many euydencis we haue of this ≈øcotland / that it is ofte called and heyghte hibernia as Irlond doth / Therfore Beda libro. ij. ca xj. ≈øeyth that laurence Archebi≈ø≈øhopp of dunbar was archebi≈ø≈øhopp of ≈øcottes that duelled in an Ilonde that hete hibernia & is
next to Britayne / Al≈øo Beda li. iij. ca. xxvij. ≈øeyth / Pe≈øtilence of mowyn bare doune hibernia / Al≈øo libro tercio ca. ij. ≈øeyth that the Scottes that duellid in the ≈øouth ≈øide of hibernia Al≈øo libro quar to ca. iij. be ≈øe ‚Ä¢ th that chadde was a yonglyng and lerned the reule of monkes in hibernia / Al≈øo li. iiij. ca. xxij. Egfridus kyng of Northumberlond de≈øtroyed hibernia / Al≈øo li. iiij. ca. xv. The mo≈øto dele of ≈øcottes in hibernia / And in the ≈øame chapitre he chepeth hibernia proprely named / that we≈øt Ilonde is an hondred myle from eueriche Britayne / and departeth with the ≈øee bitwene / and called hibernia that contrey that now is called ≈øcotlond / there he telleth that Adamuan Abbote of this Ilonde ≈øeyled to hibernia for to teche Iri≈ø≈øhmen the lawfull e≈øterday / And atte la≈øt come agayne in to ≈øcotlond / Y≈øidorus ethi. li. xiiij. Men of this ≈øcotlond ben named ≈øcott ‚Ä¢ s in their owne langage / and pictes al≈øo / For ≈øomme tyme her body was peynted in this maner / they wolde ≈øommetyme with a ≈øharpe egged tobe pricke and fierue her owne bodyes / and make theron diuer≈øe figures and ≈øhappes and peynte hem with inke or with othir peynture or colour / and becau≈øe they were ≈øo prynted they were called picti / that is to ≈øaye peynted / Erodotus / Scottes ben light of herte / ≈øtrange and wylde ynough / But by medlyng of Engli≈ø≈øhmen they ben moche amended / they ben cruell vpon theyr enemyes / and hateth bondage mo≈øt of ony thing and holde for a foule ≈ølouthe yf a man deye in his bed / And grete wor≈øhipp if he deye in the felde / They ben licell of mete and mowe fa≈øt longe / And then ≈øelde whan the ≈øunne is vp / And eten fle≈øh fi≈ø≈øh mylke and fruyt more than breed / And though they be fayre of ≈øhappe / they ben defouled and made vn≈øemely ynough with theyr owne clothyng / They pray≈øe fa≈øt the v≈øages of their owne forfndres / And de≈øpy≈øen othir mennes doyng / her londe is fruyte full ynough in pa≈øture / gardyns and feeldes / Giraldus de p. co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ xv. ij. The princes of Scottes as the kynges of ≈øpayne bene not wonte to ben enoynted ne crouned / In this Scotlond is ≈øolemp ne aud grete mynde of ≈øeint Andrew the appo≈øtle / For ≈øeint Andrew had the north contreres of the world ≈øcytes and Pictes to his lotte for to preche and conuerte the peple to Cri≈øtes beleue And at the la≈øte he was martred in Achaia in grecia in a Cyte that was named Patras / And his boones were kepte two honderd two and ≈øeuenty yere vnto Con≈øtantinus the Emperonrs tyme / And thenne they were tran≈ølated in to Con≈øtantinople and kept there C. x. yece vnto Theodo≈øtÍù∞ themÍùëours tyme Then vngu≈øt
kyng of pictes in ≈øcotland de≈øtroied a grete partie of britayne and was be≈øette with a grete hoo≈øt of britons in a feld called merke / & he herd ≈øeint Andrew ≈øpeke to hym in this maner / Vngus vngÍù∞ here thou me cri≈øtes apo≈øtle I Íùìmy≈øe the helpe & ≈øocour / whan thou ha≈øt ouercomen thyn enemyes by my helpe / thou ≈øhalt yeue the this de debe of thyn beritage in alme≈ø≈øe to god almyghty & in wor≈øhipp of ≈øeint Andrew / and the ≈øigne of the cro≈ø≈øe wente to fore his oo≈øte and the thirde day he had victorie and ≈øo torned home ayene / and deled his heritage as he was boden / And for he was vncertayne what cite he ≈øhold dele for ≈øeint Andrew / he fa≈øted thre dayes / he & his men prayd ≈øeint Andrew that he wold ≈øhewe hym what place he wold che≈øe / And one of the wardeyns that kept the body of ≈øeint Andrew in Con≈øtantinople was warned in his ≈øweuene y‚Ä¢ he ≈øhold goo in to a place whider an angele wold lede him / & ≈øo he come in to ≈øcotland with vij. felaws to y‚Ä¢ toppe of an hille named Ragmund / The ≈øame hour lighte of heuen bi≈øhone and biclipped the kyng of pictes / that was comyng with his hoo≈øt to a place called Carceuan / There anone were heled many ≈øeke men There met with the kyng Regulus the monke of Con≈øtantinople with the reliques of ≈øeint Andrew / There is founded a chirche in wor≈øhipp of ≈øeint Andrew that is hede of alle the chirches in the londe of pictes that is Scotland / To this chirche comen pilgryms oute of all londes / There was Regulus fir≈øt abbot & gadred monkes / And ≈øo alle the tienthe lond that the kyng had a≈ø≈øigned him / he departe it in diuerce places amonge abbayes

div.head: ¬∂ Of the di≈øcripcion of Irland Ca. xxij.
div.p:
HYbernia that is Irlonde / And was of olde tyme incorpe
‚Ä¢ ate in to the lord≈øhipp of Britayne ≈øo ≈øeyth Giraldus in ≈øua toppograuia / Where he di≈øcriueth it at fulle / Yet it is worthy and ≈øemely to pray≈øe that londe with larger pray≈øing / for to come to chere and full knoweleche of that londe the≈øe titles that folowe opene the weye / Therfore I ≈øhall telle of the place and ≈øtete of that londe how grete and what maner londe it is / wherof y‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de hath plente / and wherof it hath defaute / al≈øo of what men that duelled therin fir≈øt / Of maners of men of that londe / Of the wondres of that londe / aod of worthynes of halowes and ≈øeintes of that londe

div.head: ¬∂ Of the boundyng of Irlond Ca / xxiij.
div.p: IRloud is the la≈øt of all the we≈øt Ilondes & hihte hibernia of one hiberus of ≈øpayne that was hermoniÍù∞ broder / for the≈øe two brethern gate & wan that londe by conque≈øt / Or it is callid hibernia of that riuer hiberus that is m the we≈øte ende of ≈øpayne / & that londe heihte ≈øcotlond al≈øo / for ≈øcottes duellid there ≈øomtyme er they come in to that othir ≈øcotlond that longed to Britayne / Therfore it is writen in the Martiloge / Such a oay in ≈øcotlond ≈øeint Bryde was borne / & that was in Irlonde / This londe hath in the ≈øouthe≈øt ≈øide ≈øpayne thre dayes ≈øaylling thennes a ≈øide half / & hath in the e≈øt ≈øide the more britayne thens a dayes ≈øaylling in the we≈øt ≈øide it hath the endeles Occean / and in the north≈øide I≈øelond thre dayes ≈øaylling thens / Solinus / But the ≈øee that is bitwene britayne & Irlonde is all the yere full of grete wawes & vne≈øy / ≈øo that men may ≈øelde ≈øaille ≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly bitwene / that ≈øee is C. xx mybe brode

div.head: ¬∂ Of the gretnrs & qualite of that londe Capitulo. xxiiij.
div.p:
IRlonde is an Ilonde grette≈øt after britayne / and ≈øtretcheth norward from brendans hilles vnto the londe Columbina & conteyneth viij. dayes Iourneyes / euery Iourney of xl. myle / and from deuelin to patrike hilles & to the ≈øee in that ≈øide in brede foure Iourneyes / and Irlonde is nawwer in the myddell than in thendes / all othirwy≈øe than britayne is / as Irlonde is ≈øhorter northward than britayne / ≈øo is it lenger ≈øouthward / the londe is not pleyne but full of montayns of hilles of wodes of mareys and of mores / The londe is ≈øofte rayny wyndy & lowr by the ≈øer ≈øide & withinne hilly & ≈øondy / SolinÍù∞ / ther is grete plente of noble pa≈øture & of lee≈øe / therfor the bee≈øtes mu≈øt be oft driuen out of their pa≈øture bee≈øt they ‚Ä¢ te ouermoch for they ≈øhold ≈øhende hem ≈øelf if they myght ete at their wyll / Girald men of that londe haue communely their helth and ≈øtrangers haue ofte a perilous flux becau≈øe of the moi≈øture of the mete / The fle≈ø≈øh of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ren is there hol≈øome / and ≈øwynes fle≈ø≈øh vnhol≈øome / Men of that londe haue no feuer but only the feuer ague & that right ≈øelde Therfor the hol≈øomnes & helthe of that londe & the clennes out of venyme is worth all the hoo≈øt & riche≈ø≈øe of trees of herbes of ≈øpycerie / of riche clothes / & of precious ≈øtones of the e≈øt londes The can ‚Ä¢ e of the helthe & hol≈øomnrs of that londe is y‚Ä¢ atteÃÑÍùëate hete & colde that is therin In qui
bus re
bus ≈øufficit
In this londe ben mo kyne than oxen / more pa≈øture than corne / more gras than ≈øeed / There is grete plente of ≈øamon / of lamprayes / of Eelis and of othir ≈øee fi≈ø≈øh / Of egles of cranes / of pecokes / of curlewes / of ≈øperhaukes / of go≈øhaukes and of gentill fawcons / Of wolues and right ≈øhrewd my≈øe / Ther ben attercoppes / blode ≈øoukers and ecftes that doon none harme / Ther ben feyres lytill of body and full hardy and ≈øtronge / Ther ben bernacles fowles lyke to wylde ghees / whiche growen wonderly vpon trees / at it were nature wrought agayn kynde / men of religion eteth bernacles on fa≈øtingdayes becau≈øe they ben not engendrid with fle≈ø≈øh / wherein as me thinketh they erre / for re≈øon is ayen≈øt that / For yf a man had eten of Adams begge he had eten fle≈ø≈øh / and yet Adam was not engendrid of fader and moder / But that fle≈ø≈øh come wonderly of therthe / and ≈øo this fle≈ø≈øh cometh wonderly of the tree In this londe is plente of hony and of mylke of wyne and of vyneyerdes / Solinus and Y≈øidorus writen that Irlonde hath no bees / Netheles it were better writen that Irlonde had
‚Ä¢ ees and no vynyerdes Al≈øo Beda ≈øeyth that ther is grete hunting to roobuckes And it is y knowe that there ben none / It is no wonder of Beda for he ≈øaw neuer that londe / but ≈øomme man had told hym ≈øuche tales / Al≈øo ther groweth that ≈øtone Saxagonus and is called Iris al≈øo as it were the rayn bowe / yf that ≈øtone be holde agayn≈øt the ≈øonne a none it ≈øhall ≈øhape a raynbowe / ther is al≈øo founden a ≈øtone that is called gagates and white margery perles

div.head: ¬∂ Of the defawtes of the londe Ca. xxv
div.p:
WHete cornes ben there full ≈ømall vnnethe yclen≈øed with mannes hond / Re≈øerued men / alle be≈øtes ben ≈ømaller ther than in othir londes / Ther lacketh well nygh alle maner fy≈ø≈øh of fre≈ø≈øhe water that is not gendrid in the ≈øee Ther lacken vnkynde faucons / gerfaucons / partrychis fe≈øaunte / Nyghtyngals & pyes / Ther lacken al≈øo Roo and bucke and Ile≈øpiles wontes and othir venymous be≈øtes / Therfore ≈øommen feynen and that fauourably that ≈øeint patryk clen≈øed that lond of wormes and of venymous be≈øtes / but it is more probable and more ≈økylfull that this londe was from the beginnyng alway withoute ≈øuche wormes / for venemous be≈øtes and wormes dyen ther anone yf men bringe hem thiter oute of othir londes And al≈øo venyme and poy≈øon brought thider oute of othir londes le≈øen theyr malice as ≈øone as it pa≈ø≈øeth
the myddell of the ≈øee / Al≈øo poudr ‚Ä¢
and erthe of that londe ca≈øte & ≈øawen in othir londes driuen away wormes ≈øo ferforth that yf a turf of that lond be put aboute a worme / it ≈øleth hym or maketh hym thrille the erthhe for te≈øcape away / In that londe cockes crow but litill to fore day / ≈øo that the fir≈øt crowyng of cockes in that londe and the thirde in othir londes ben like ferre to fore the day

div.head: ¬∂ Of them that fir≈øt enhabited Irlonde Ca. xxvj.
div.p:
GYraldus ≈øeyth that Ca≈øera Nors nece drad the flode and fledde with thre men and fyfty wymmen in to that Ilonde and duelled therin fir≈øt the la≈øt yere to fore Noes flode / But afterward Bartholanus Seres ≈øone that come of Iaphet Noes ≈øone come thether with his thre ≈øones by happe or by crafte / CCC. yere after Noes flode and duelled there and encreced to the nombre of ix. M. men / And afterward for ≈øtenche of ka ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eyns of geantes that they had kyld they deyden alle ≈øaue one Ruanuz that lyued a thou≈øand and V. C. yere vnto ≈øeint patriks tyme / and enformed the holy man of the for≈øaid men and of all their doyngis and dedes / Thenne the thirde tyme come thider Nymeth oute of ≈øcicia with his foure ≈øones and duelled there two houndred yere and xvj. And atte la≈øt of his of≈øpring by diuer≈øe my≈øhappes of werres and of moreyne they were clene de≈øtroied and the londe lefte wyde CC. yere after / The fourthe tyme fyue dukes that were bretheren / Gandius / Genandus / Saganduis / Ruth ‚Ä¢ ragus / SlauiÍù∞ / of the for≈øaid Nimethis ≈øucce≈ø≈øours come oute of Grece and ocupied that londe and deled it in fyue parties / And euery partye conteyned xxij. candredes / A candrede is a contre that conteyneth an houndred tounes / And they ≈øette a ≈øtone in the myddell of the londe as it were in the nauell and beginnyng of fyue kyngdomes Atte la≈øt Slauius was made kyng of all the londe / The fyfthe tyme whaÃÑ this nacion was xxx. yere to gedyr they wexe feble Four noble men that were Mille≈øius the kyngs ≈øones come oute of ≈øpayne with many othir in a naueye of lx. ≈øhippes / And two of the worthie≈øt of the≈øe foure brethern that hete Hiberus and Hermon deled the lond bitwene hem tweyne / But afterward couenaunt was broken bitwene hem bothe and Hiberus was ≈ølawe / Thenne Hermon was kyng of all that londe / And from his tyme to the fir≈øt patriks tyme were kynges of that nacion C. xxxj. And ≈øo fro the comyng of the hybermen≈øis vnto the fir≈øt patrik were a M.
yere & viij. C. They had that name hibermences and hibernia of the for≈øaid hiberus or els of hiberus a riuer of ≈øpayne / they were called al≈øo Gaytels and ≈øcottes / of one gaytelus that was phenius neuew / This gaytelus coude ≈øpeke many langages / after the langages that were made at nemproths tour / and wedded one ≈øcotta phawes doughter / Of the≈øe dukes come the hibermen≈øis / Men ≈øaie that this gaytelus made the Iri≈ø≈øh langage and called it gaytelaf as it were a langage gadred / of all langages and tonges / Atte la≈øt Belinus kyng of Britayne had a ≈øone hihte gur guncius / As this Gurguncius come oute of denmarke atte Ilondes Orcades / he fonde men that were called ba≈øclen≈øis and were come thider oute of ≈øpayne / thy≈øe men prayde and be≈øoughte for to haue place to duelle inne / And the kyng ≈øente hem to Irlonde that was tho wyde and wa≈øte / and ordeyned and ≈øente with hem dnkes and capitaynes of his owne / And ≈øo it ≈øemeth that Irlonde ≈øhold longe to Britayne by right of olde tyme / From the fir≈øt ≈øeynt patrik vnto Fedliundius the kynges tyme CCCC. yere / regned xxxiij. kynges euerich after othir in Irlonde / In this Fedliundius tyme Turge≈øius duke and captayne of Norweyes brought thider men of Norweye and ocupied that londe and made in many places depe diches & ca≈øtels ≈øengle double and treble and many wardes ≈øtrongly walled / and many therof ≈øtonde yet alle hole / but Iri≈ø≈øhmen recche not of ca≈øtels / for they take woodes for ca≈øtels and mareys and mores for ca≈øtell diches / But atte la≈øte Turge≈øius deyde by gylefull wyles of women / and Engli≈ø≈øhmen ≈øeyne that Gurmundus wan Irlonde & made thilke diches / and ma ke no mencion of Turge≈øias / and Iri≈ø≈øhmen ≈øpeke of turge≈øiÍù∞ and knowe not of Gurmundus Therfor it is to wete that gurmuÃÑ dus had wonne britayne & duellid therin / and ≈øende Turge≈øius with grete ≈øtrength in to Irlonde for to wynne that londe / and bycau≈øe Turge≈øius was captayne & leder of that viage & Iourney and ≈øeen amonge them Therfore Iri≈ø≈øhmen ≈øpeke moche of hym as a noble man that was ≈øeen in that londe and knowen / Atte la≈øte whan Gurmundus was ≈ølayne in fraunce / Turge≈øius loued the kynges doughter of mete in Irlonde / & her fader behihte Turge≈øiÍù∞ that he wold ≈øende her him to the lowe larherin with xv. maydens And Turge≈øius promy≈øed to mete there with xv. of the noble≈øte men that he had / and helde couenaunt and thought no gyle / but ther come xv. yong berdles men clothed like wymmen with ≈øhort ≈øwerdes vnder her clothes / & fille on Turge≈øius & ≈ølowe him right
there and ≈øo he was traitour≈øly ≈ølayne after he had regned xxx. yere / Not longe after thre brethern Amelanus Siracus & Iuorus come in to Irlond with hir men oute of Norwey as it had ben for ≈øoue of pees and of marchandyfe and duellid by the ≈øee ≈øides by a≈ø≈øente of Iri≈ø≈øhmen / that were alway ydle as poules knyghtes / And the Norwayes bilded thre citees / Deuelin Waterford and lymerich and encreced and after wexe rebell ayen≈øt men of that londe and brought fir≈øt ≈øparthes in to Irlond / So fro Turge≈øiÍù∞ tyme vnto Rotheriks tyme kyng of Connaccia that was the la≈øt that was kyng of all the londe were xvij. kynges in Irlonde And ≈øo the kynges that regned in Irlonde from the fir≈øt hermons tyme vnto the la≈øte Rotheriks tyme were in all an C. lxxxj. kynges y‚Ä¢ were not crouned nethir enoynted ne by lawe of heritage / but by myght mai≈øtrye and by ≈øtrength of armes The ≈øeconde harry kyng of englond made this Rotherik ≈øubgete the yere of kyng harryes age fourty / and of his regne xvij / the yere our lord xj. C. lxxij.

div.head: ¬∂ Of the condicions and maners of Iri≈ø≈øhmen Ca. xxvij.
div.p:
SOlinus ≈øeyth that men of this londe ben ≈øtrange of nacoÃÑn hou≈øeles and grete fighters / and acounte right & wrong all for one thyng / and ben ≈øingle of clothyng / ≈øcar≈øe of mete cruel of herte / angri of ≈øpeche / and drinketh fir≈øt blode of dede men that ben ≈ølayne / and thenne we≈ø≈øhen their vi≈øages ther with and holde hem payd with fle≈ø≈øh & fruyt in ≈øtede of mete and with mylke in ≈øtede of drynke / And v≈øen moche pleyeng Idlenes and hunting and trauaylle but litell In their childhode they ben hard nori≈ø≈øhed and hard fed and they be vnfemely of maners and of clothyng and haue breche and ho≈øen allone of wolle & ≈øtrayte hodes that ≈øtretcheth a cubite ouer the ≈øholdres behynde and foldinges in ≈øtede of mantels & of clokes / Al≈øo they v≈øe no ≈øadles / bootes ne ≈øpores whan they ryde / but they driue their hor≈øes with a chambred yerd in the ouer ende / In ≈øtede of bittes with trenches & of badles of ree≈øt / they v≈øe bridles that lette not their hor≈øe to ete their mete / They fighte vnarmed naked in body / netheles with ij. dartes & ≈øperes / & with brode ≈øparthes they fight with one hande / The≈øe men for≈øake tylyeng of londe and kepen pa≈øture for bee≈øtes / they v≈øe longe herdes & longe lockes hangyng doune behinde her hedes / They v≈øe no crafte of flaxe / of wolle / of metall / ne of marchaÃÑ dy≈øe / but yeue hem to Idlenes & to ≈ølouthe / & rekene ro≈øte for liking
and fredome for riche≈ø≈øe / And though ≈øcotlond the doughter of Illonde v≈øe harpe tymbre & talour / Netheles Iri≈ø≈øhmen be connyng in two maner in≈øtrumentis of mu≈øtke / in harpe & tymbre that is armed with wyre & ≈øtrenges of bra≈ø≈øe / In whiche in≈øtrumentis though they plaxe ha≈øtely & ≈øwyftly they make right mery armonye & melodye with thicke tewnes werbles & notes / & beginne froÃÑ bemol & playen ≈øecretly vnder dyme ≈øoune in the grete ≈øtrenges / & torne ayene vnto the ≈øame / ≈øo that the grette≈øt Íùëtie of the craft hydeth the craft / as it wolde ≈øeme as though the craft ≈øo hidde ≈øholde be a≈øhamed if it were take / The≈øe men „Äà‚óä„Äâ of euyll maners in her lyuyng / they paye no tithinges they wedde lawfully / they ≈øpare not their alyes / but the brother wedded the brothers wyf / they ben be≈øy for to betraye her neyhbours & other / they here ≈øparthes in their londes in ≈øtede of ≈øtaues & fighte ayen≈øt them / that tru≈øte mo≈øte to them / The≈øe men ben variable and vn≈øtedfa≈øt trechours & gylefull who that deleth with them / nedeth more to beware of gyle / than of craft of pecs than of brennyng brondes / of hony than of galle / of malice than of knyghthode / they haue ≈øuch maners that they ben not ≈øtronge in werre & in bataill ne trewe in pecs / they become go≈ø≈øibs to them / that they well fal≈øely betraye in the go≈ø≈øibrede and holy kynrede / Euerich drinketh others blode whan it is ≈øhed They loue ≈øomdele her norice & her pleyfers whiche that ≈øouke the ≈øame mylke that they ≈øouked while they were children / And they pour ≈øiewe their brethern their co≈øins / and their othir kyn / And de≈øpi≈øen their kyn whiles they lyue / and auenge their deth whan they ben ≈ølayne / So longe hath the v≈øage of euyll cu≈øtome endured among them / that it hath goten the ma≈øtrie ouer them & torneth tre≈øon in to kynde ≈øo ferforth that they ben traitours by nature / And aliens and men of ≈øtraunge londes that duelle amonge them folowen their maners that vnnethe ther is none but he is bi≈ømytted with their tre≈øon al≈øo / Amonge them many men pi≈ø≈øen ≈øitting and wymmen ≈øtandyng / Ther ben many men in that londe foul ≈øhapen in lymiues and in body / For in their lymmes they lak the benefice of kynde So that no wher ben none better ≈øhapen than they that ben there well ≈øhapen / and none wor≈øe ≈øhapen than they that bene euyll ≈øhapen / And ≈økylfully nature hurte & defouled by wykednes of lyuyng bringeth forth ≈øuche foule gromes & euyll ≈øhapen of bein that with vnlawfull delyng with foule maners & euyll lyuyng ≈øo wyckedly defouleth kynde & nature In this lond & in wales olde wyuce & wymen were wonte & ben yet as men ≈øeyne
ofte for to ≈øhape them ≈øelfe in likenes of hares for to mylke their neyghbours kyne and ≈øtele her mylke / And ofte grehoundes rennen after them and pour≈øiewe them and wenen that they be hares Al≈øo ≈øome by craft of Nygromancie maken fatte ≈øwyne for to be rede of colour and ≈øelle them in markettis & in feyres / But a≈ø≈øone as the≈øe ≈øwyne pa≈ø≈øe ony water they torne in to their owne kynde whether it be ≈øtrawe heye gras or turues But the≈øe ≈øwyne may not be kept by no craft for tendure in likenes of ≈øwyne ouer thre dayes Amonge the≈øe wondres & othir take bede that in the vtterme≈øt ende of the worlde falleth ofte new meruailles and wondres / As though kynde pleyde with larger loue ≈øecretly & fex in thendes / that openly & neyh the myddell / therfore in this Ilonde ben many gry≈øly wondres and meruailles

div.head: ¬∂ Of the meruailles & wondres of Irlonde Ca. xxviij.
div.p:
MAny men tellen that in the north≈øide of Irlonde is the londe of lyf / In that Ilonde noman may deye / but whaÃÑ they ben olde and ben vexed with grete ≈øekene≈ø≈øe / they ben born oute in to the next londe and deye there / Ther is anothir Ilonde in Irlonde that no woman therin may bere a childe / but yet ≈øhe may conceyue / Al≈øo ther is an Ilonde in which no dede body may roten In vltonia that is vl≈øter is an Ilonde in a lake wonderly departed in tweyne / In that one partie is grete di≈øturbaunce & de≈øcomfort of fendes / and in that othir partie grete likyng and comfort of holy angels / There is al≈øo ≈øeynt patriks purgatorie that was ≈øhewed at his prayers to confirme his prechyng & his lore whan he preched to my≈øbeleued meÃÑ of ≈øorowe & peyne that euyl men ≈øholde ≈øuffre for her wicked wirkes / And of Ioye and of bli≈ø≈øe that good men ≈øhall re≈ø≈øeyue for her holy dedes / he telleth that who that ≈øuffreth y‚Ä¢ peynes of y‚Ä¢ purgatorie / yf it be enioyned hym for penauÃÑ ce / he ≈øhall neuer ≈øuffre the peynes of helle / but he dye finally withoute repetaunce of ≈øinne / as the en≈øample is ≈øette more fulle / at this chapitres ende / Treui≈øa / But truly noman / may be ≈øaued but if he be veri repentaunt what ≈øomeuer penaunce he doo / and euery man that is very repentaunt at his lyues ende / ≈øhall be ≈øikerly ≈øaued / though he neuer here of ≈øeint patriks purgatorie / Ther is an Ilonde in Connacte Salo / that is in the ≈øee of Conaccia / halewed by ≈øeint Brandan / that hath no my≈øe / there dede bodyes ben not buried / but ben kept oute of therthe & roten not / In mamonia is a welle / who
that wa≈ø≈øheth him with that water of that welle / he ≈øhall wexe hore on his hede / Ther is anothir welle in vltonia / who ≈øomeuer is we≈ø≈øhen therin he ≈øhall neuer wexe hore afterward / Ther is a welle in Moun≈øtre or Momonia / yf ony man touche that welle anone ≈øhall falle grete rayne in all the prouynce / & that rayne ≈øhall neuer ce≈ø≈øe till a pree≈øt that is a clene mayde ≈øinge a ma≈ø≈øe in a chapell fa≈øt by & ble≈ø≈øe the water / And with mylke of a cowe that is of one heer be≈øpringe the welle / & ≈øo reconcyle the welle in this ≈øtrange maner At Glindalcan aboute the oratorie of ≈øeint keywyn with ges berith apples as it were apple trees / and ben mow hol≈øome thaÃÑ ≈øau ‚Ä¢ ry / That holy ≈øeint brought forth the≈øe apples by prayers for to hele his childe that was ≈øeek / Ther is a lake in bl≈øter and moche fi≈ø≈øh therin / which is xxx. myle in lengthe and fiften in brede The Riuer Ban renneth oute of that lake in to the north Occean / And men ≈øaye that this lake began in this maner / There were men in that contrey that were of euyll lyuyng / coeuntes cum brutis / And there was a welle in that londe in grete reuerence of olde tyme / and alwaye couerd / and yf it were lefte vncouerd the welle wold u≈øe and drowne all the londe / And ≈øo it happed that a woman wente to that welle for to fecche water and hihed her fa≈øte to her childe that wepte in the cradle / and lefte the welle vncouered / then the welle ≈øprang ≈øo fa≈øt that it drowned the woman and her childe and made all the contre a lake and a fi≈ø≈øhponde / For to preue that this is ≈øoth it is a grete argument / that whan the weder is clere / fi≈ø≈øhers of that water ≈øee in the grouÃÑde vnder the water rounde touris and hihe ≈øhapen as ≈øteples and chirches of that londe In the north≈øide of Irlonde in the contre of o≈ø≈øiriens / euery vij. yere at the prayer of an holy Abbot / tweyne that ben wedded a man and a woman mo≈øt nedes ben exiled & for≈øhapen in to likenes of wolues and abyde oute vij. yere / And atte ende of vij. yere if they lyue they come home agayn and take agayn their owne ≈øhappe / and thenne ≈øhall othir tweyne goo forth in their ≈øtede / and ≈øo for ≈øhapen for othir vij. yere / There is a lake in this londe if a poole of tree be pyght and ≈øtyked therin that parte of the ≈øhaft or poole that is in therthe ≈øhall torne in to Iren / And that parte that abydeth in the water / ≈øhall torne in to ≈øtone / And the parte that abideth aboue ≈øhall be tre in his owne kynde / Al≈øo ther is a lake that torneth ha≈øell into a≈ø≈øhe and a≈ø≈øhe in to ha≈øell / if it be don therin / Al≈øo in Irlonde „Äà‚óä„Äâ thre ≈øamon leepes / there as ≈øamons lepe ayen≈øt a roche a longe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ res length Al≈øo in lagenia is a ponde ther he ≈øeeÃÑ colmans
birdes / the byrdes ben cleped certelles and come homly to mannes honde / but yf men doo hem wronge or harme / they gone awaye and come not agayne / and the water ther ≈øhall wexe bitter and ≈øtynke / And he that dyde the wronge ≈øhall not a ≈øterte withoute wreche and me≈øchief but yf he doo amendes / R / As touching patriks purgatorie / ye ≈øhall vnder≈øtande that the ≈øecond ≈øeint Patrik that was Abbot and not bi≈ø≈øhopp while he prechid in Irlonde labourid and ≈øtudyed for to torne thilke wicked men that lyued as be≈øtes out of her euyll lyf for drede of peynes of belle / and for to coÃÑferme hem in good lyf / and they ≈øeyde they wold not torne but ≈øomme of them myght knowe ≈øomwhat of the grete paynes / and al≈øo of bli≈ø≈øe that he ≈øpake of / Thenne ≈øeint patrik prayed to god almyghty therfore / and our lord Ihe≈øus cri≈øt appierid to ≈øeint patrik „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ hym a ≈øtafe and ladde him in to a wylde place and ≈øhe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d hi ‚Ä¢ there a round pitte that was derke within & ≈øaide / that yf a man were veri repentaunt and ≈øtable of byleue and wente in to this pitte / and walked therin a day and a nyght / he ≈øhold ≈øee the ≈øorowes and the peynes of euyll men / and the Ioye and bly≈ø≈øe of good men Thenne cri≈øt vany≈ø≈øhed oute of patriks ≈øight / and ≈øeint Patrik arered and bylded there a chirche and put therin Chanons reguler & clo≈øed the pitte aboute with a walle / & is now in the chirch yerd atte ce≈øt ende of the chirch / & fa≈øt ≈øhitte with a ≈øtronge dore / For noman ≈øhold nycely goo in withoute leue of the bi≈ø≈øhopp / or of the priour of the place / Many men wente in and come oute agayn in patriks tyme and tolde of paynes & Ioye that they had ≈øeen-and the meruailles that they ≈øawe ben there yet wreton And becau≈øe therof many men torned & were conuerted to right bileue / Al≈øo many men wente in and come neuer ayen / In kyng Stephens tyme kyng of Englond a knyght that hihte Owayne wente in to ≈øeint patriks purgatorie and come agayn and duelled euer after during his lyf in the nedes of thabbay of luden≈øis that is of thordre of Ci≈øtews and tolde many wondres that he had ≈øeeÃÑ in patriks purgatorie / The place is called Patriks purgatorye and the chirche is named reglis / Noman is enioyned for to goo in to that purgatorie / But counceilled that he ≈øhold not come therin but take vpon him othir penaunce / And yf a man haue auowed and be ≈øtable and wole nede too therin / he ≈øhall fir≈øt god to the bi≈ø≈øhop & then he ≈øhall be ≈øente with lrÃÑes to the priour of „Äà‚óä„Äâ place & they bothe ≈øhall couÃÑceill him to leue / & if he will nedes „Äà‚óä„Äâ therto he ≈øhall be in prayers & in fa≈øting xv. dayes / and after „Äà‚óä„Äâ he
≈øhall be hou≈øeld & lad to the dore of the purgatorie with proce≈ø≈øion and letanie / and yet he ≈øhall be counceilled to leue it / and yf he be ≈øtedfa≈øt and wyll entre / the dore ≈øhall be opend and he y ble≈ø≈øed & goo in on goddis name / and holde forth his waye / and the dore ≈øhall be fa≈øt ≈øhette tyll the next day / and whan the tyme is the priour ≈øhall come & opene the dore / and yf the man be comen he bedeth hym in to the chirch with proce≈ø≈øion / and there he ≈øhall be xv. daye ‚Ä¢ in prayers and fa≈øtyng

div.head: ¬∂ Of the meruailles of ≈øeyntes of Irlonde Ca. xxix.
div.p:
HEre Giraldus maketh mynde that as meÃÑ of this nacion ben more angri than othir men & more ha≈øty for to take wreche whiles they ben a lyue / ≈øo ≈øeyntes and halowys of this londe ben more wrechefull than ≈øeintes of othir londes / Clerkes of this londe ben cha≈øte & ≈øayen many prayers & done grete ab≈øtinence a daye / and drynketh all nyght / ≈øo that is acounted for a myracle / that lecherye regneth not there as wyne regneth / and they that ben euyll of them ben wor≈øt of all othir / So good men among them though they be but fewe / ben good atte be≈øte Prelates of that contrey ben but ≈ølowe in correction of tre≈øpas / and be≈øy in contemplacion and not in prechyng of goddis worde / Therfore it is that alle the ≈øeintes of that londe ben confe≈ø≈øours and no martir amoÃÑg them / and no wonder / for all the prelates of this londe ben cho≈øen oute of abbeyes in to the clergye / and done as monkes ≈øholde / what clerkes and prelates ≈øhuld do is to them vnknowen / therfor whan it was put ayen≈øt the bi≈ø≈øhopp of Ca≈ø≈øyll how it myght be that ≈øo many ≈øeintes ben in Irlonde and neuer a martir among hem all ≈øith that the men ben ≈øo ≈øhrewd and ≈øo angri / and the prelates ≈øo recheles and ≈ølowe in corrections of tre≈øpas / The bi≈ø≈øhopp an≈øuerd feowa dly ynowh and ≈øayde / oure men ben ≈øhrewd & angri ynouh to hem ≈øelfe / but to goddes ≈øeruauntes they beye neuer honde but do to hem grete reuerence and wor≈øhipp / But engli≈ø≈øhmen come in to this londe that kan make martres / and were wonte to v≈øe that crafte / R / The bi≈ø≈øhop ≈øaid ≈øo bicau≈øe that kyng harry the ≈øeconde was tho new comen in to Irlonde fre≈ø≈øhly after the martirdome of ≈øeint Thomes of Caunterbury / Gir. in this londe in wales and in ≈øcotland ben belles and ≈øtaues with croked hedes & othir ≈øuch thynges for reliques in grete reuerence & wor≈øhipp / ≈øo that men of this londe dreden more for to ≈øwere vpon ony of thilke belles and gold
≈øtaues than vpon the go≈øpell / The chief of alle ≈øuche reliques is y holde IhuÃÑs ≈øtaf / that is at deuelin / with the whiche ≈øtaf they ≈øaye y‚Ä¢ the fir≈øt ≈øeint patrik drofe the wormes out of Irlonde / AugÍù∞. de. ci. dei ca. vij. Yf men axe how it may be that diuer≈øe maner bee≈øtis & of diuer≈øe kynde that ben kindly goten bitwene male & female come & ben in Ilondes after Noes flode / Men ≈øuppo≈øen that ≈øuche bee≈øtes ≈øwame in to Ilondes aboute. and fir≈øt to the nexte & ≈øo forth into othir / Or els men ≈øeyllyng in to Ilondes brought with hem ≈øuch bee≈øtis for loue of hunting / or angels at god almyghties commauÃÑ dement brou»ùt ≈øuche bee≈øtes in to Ilondes aboute / or the erthe brou»ùt hem forth fir≈øt & fulfilled tho goddes commaundement / that commaunded the erthe to bringe forth gras & quycke bee≈øtes.
div.trailer: Here endeth the di≈øcripcion of Britayne the / whiche conteyneth englond wales and ≈øcotland / & al≈øo bicau≈øe Irlonde is vnder the reule of englond & of olde tyme it hath ≈øo continued therfore I haue ≈øette the de≈øcripcion of the ≈øame after the ≈øaid brituyne / which I haue taken oute of Policronicon / And bicau≈øe it is nece≈ø≈øarie to alle engli≈ø≈øhmen to knowe the propretees coÃÑmoditees & meruailles of them / therfore I haue ≈øette them in enprinte according to the tran≈ølacion of Creui≈øa / whiche atte reque≈øt of the lord Barkeley tran≈ølated the book of Policronicon in to engli≈ø≈øh / Fyny ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hed by me william Carton the xviij. day of Augu≈øt the yere of our lord god M. CCCC. lxxx. and the xx. yere of the regne of kyng Edward the fourthe.
